TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer whether the statement by the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support in the House last week that he expected the implicit price deflator to `come in at around 10 per cent, maybe a little below' is a revised Government forecast for inflation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of what the Minister said. But I am aware of what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said last week when looking at the non-farm product deflator. He failed either to understand or to imply that export prices, which are part and parcel of the implicit price deflator for gross non-farm product, were rising at a rate of 8.9 per cent. He was telling the world-anyone who wanted to listen-that, basically, we had the implicit price deflator in the national accounts at 8.9 per cent and, therefore, inflation was rising. One would have thought that commonsense should have told both him and the honourable member for Wentworth that, given that generally Australians do not consume exports, the more accurate reflection of prices was an expenditure deflator. The non-farm product deflator, of course, was boosted by these higher export prices whereas the private consumption deflator rose by 1.5 per cent to be 7.1 per cent higher than a year earlier. But the broadest price deflator of what people actually spend in the economy-that is, the deflator for gross national expenditure-rose by 0.9 per cent in the quarter.
—He has lost himself; he has to read it.

—I am quoting these figures from the national accounts. This rose from 0.9 per cent in the quarter to be 6 per cent higher than a year earlier. So on the broadest deflator, that is the deflator for gross national expenditure, inflation was rising by 6 per cent and, on the private consumption deflator, by 7.1 per cent, which is about where the Government said inflation would be but for the distortion caused by housing prices in the consumer price index (CPI). Interestingly, the private consumption deflator rose by 1.5 per cent in that quarter, the very same quarter when we had a 2.1 per cent rise in the CPI, which only demonstrates yet again that there was a huge distortion because of the measurement of mortgage costs under that methodology.

ANSWER.PARA: But the punch line is that the shadow Treasurer and shadow finance Minister did not understand that the measure of inflation was better provided by a reference to those expenditure and consumption deflators; rather, they chose the implicit price deflator, which includes exports. Apparently they are quite happy to mislead the public that inflation is running at 8.9 per cent when they understand that that increase is a result of the increase in export prices, which are part of the non-farm implicit price deflator. Before honourable members opposite start asking any more questions about the inflation rate they should understand what the measures are.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE: TRADE NEGOTIATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister advise the House of the outcome of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) trade negotiations in Geneva over the past few days, particularly as they relate to agriculture?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hinkler for his question. I am very pleased to inform the House-I know that it will be of interest to all honourable members, irrespective of their political affiliations-that a major breakthrough in multilateral trade negotiations occurred in Geneva over the weekend. The log jam in negotiations that developed in Montreal in December and the mid-term review has been broken.

ANSWER.PARA: On agriculture, in essence the GATT parties have accepted all the major elements of the Cairns Group proposal that I tabled in Geneva on behalf of the Cairns Group in October 1987. They are: first, a commitment to long term liberalisation of world agricultural markets to begin in 1991, the year after the conclusion of the GATT talks; second, until that reform process starts, an immediate freeze on farm subsidies and at least the maintenance of market access at existing levels; third and finally, a commitment to reduce farm support and protection levels in 1990-that is, before the long term reform process gets under way.

As a result of those negotiations the basis is laid for Australian farmers to look forward to improved rural returns and a massive change for the better over the debilitating effects that they have suffered from the European Economic Community (EEC)-United States agricultural subsidy war and the unfair trade barriers that have been associated with that situation in those countries and elsewhere.

A great deal of credit for this breakthrough goes to the 14 countries that constitute the Cairns Group of fair traders. There is no question-it is accepted now as a fact of international life-that the Cairns Group has acted as a powerful third voice in the GATT agricultural trade negotiations and it has succeeded in breaking the deadlock that has existed between the EEC and the United States over the past several years. It should be a matter of great pride to all Australians that Australia has chaired the Cairns Group from its inception. In that respect I specifically pay tribute to two Ministers: first, the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy). He and his officials have worked tirelessly towards achieving this breakthrough. I can say, from the communications I have received from around the world, that it is quite clear that the personal dealings of Minister Duffy, with other trade Ministers, have been instrumental in securing such a good outcome. We are indebted to the Minister.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —His cup floweth over. He has had this breakthrough this weekend and, after the weekend, Essendon is still on top. It is appropriate that, as well as properly paying tribute to Minister Duffy, I-I hope, again, that I speak for the whole House-pay tribute to the former trade Minister, the present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), whose initiative it was to establish the Cairns Group in the first place. The outcome of this weekend is a tribute to both Ministers.

ANSWER.PARA: Madam Speaker, as you know, and as I think all Australians are aware, the Government has been unrelenting in its pursuit, through all available forums, of a freer and fairer international agricultural trading system. While we need to remain diligent in ensuring that the principles of this last weekend in Geneva are transformed into practice, I believe there is no doubt that we can say, as a result of this weekend's breakthrough, that there is now considerable room for optimism for the future of efficient agricultural producers in general, and most particularly for Australian farmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I remind him that the latest report on home loan affordability shows that the average Australian home loan repayment increased by $206 a month between December 1987 and December 1988. I ask him: What is his estimate of the impact of the rise in mortgage interest rates since December 1988 on home loan affordability?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The affordability index is based around a median price, and in the first home owners market home prices are mostly well below the median. To that extent the index is not particularly an indication of the costs in terms of affordability to first home owners; it is at best a guide. The ratio is not a guide to the situation of those with existing home loans because they are not adversely affected by house prices, having already bought a home. These indexes always rise whenever house prices rise.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have often said in the House and will repeat, the great problem that new home buyers face is not just the increase in home loan interest rates, which is now of a couple of percentage points, but the fact that the mortgage is so much higher because of higher house prices. The reason we have higher house prices is in the main a lack of housing supply. That is the issue which the Government addressed at the housing conference with the Premiers and this is why the States have the major role to play in adding to the supply of housing. While higher interest rates certainly impose a burden on new home buyers and those changing homes, the greatest burden is applied by the inflation of house prices, the actual size of the mortgage, and that is a consequence of a failure of the States to complement supply.

On the note of housing prices, I saw today in the Sydney Daily Telegraph a comment by the chief economist of Citibank Ltd, one of the most irresponsible comments in recent times about interest rates for housing. This person was predicting that in the next day or two housing interest rates would go to 18 per cent. I can only say that if the price the community has to pay for having banks put their names before the public is for all these hired economists to make the most outrageous, inflated estimates of interest rates, the more responsible institutions, particularly the Commonwealth Bank and Westpac Banking Corporation, which have given indications of the real impact of current commercial rates on interest rates, have given a much better guide over time than some of the more irresponsible comments such as the one reported today.

None of this is helped by members of the Opposition, who not only do not have a housing policy but do not even have an economic policy or a fiscal policy. One day they are going to have a larger Budget surplus and the next day less; one day they are asking questions about interest rates and housing affordability, and the next day one of their spokesmen, mainly the shadow finance spokesman, is urging higher interest rates to slow down economic activity. All this means that the community can take no guide from members of the Opposition as to where they stand on fiscal policy, monetary policy or housing. I simply conclude with the point that in 1981, under the then treasurership of Mr Howard, we saw this affordability index rise. What happened then was that we saw 22 per cent interest rates in commercial rates. Current rates have not reached these levels yet, and will not.

—Does the Treasurer recall the words of the former Minister for Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Gellibrand, who told the 1987 Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress that failure to keep Australian wage rises in line with those of our overseas competitors would place us in `dire economic peril'? Is the Treasurer aware that we now have the fastest rate of growth in unit labour costs of any Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) country, with the possible exception of Sweden? Is he also aware that we also now have the highest rate of inflation of any major industrialised country? I also ask the Treasurer whether he is aware that the annual growth in unit labour costs in Australia since he became Treasurer has been, on average, 46 per cent faster than for the OECD as a whole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am also aware that unit labour cost declines are larger in Australia than in any other OECD country. I am also aware that inflation is rising around the world. In the British Budget the forecast is for inflation to peak at 8.6 per cent. Our inflation trajectory is still declining, albeit not as fast as we would like. Why did inflation rise from the 5 per cent this Government succeeded in getting it to, after the previous Government left it at 11 per cent, to the 5.1 per cent it was for the year to March 1985? It rose because of a substantial fall in the Australian dollar. Why did that happen? Honourable members opposite left the place uncompetitive, following a wages explosion in 1980-81 and policy indolence over 25 years; that is why.

ANSWER.PARA: Fancy honourable members opposite getting up in this Parliament and talking about wages policy, when the Leader of the Opposition presided over a 17 percentage-point increase in wages in 1980-81, which gave us a wages explosion and the deepest recession since the Great Depression. Honourable members opposite, who have no policy change, no other policy, and who have opposed every wage increase since 1983, have the hide now to suggest that, by implication, they have a policy which would not allow that to happen again. If they were in government right now we would have wages running at about 15 per cent, inflation on the way back to double digits and a recession following. Not one bit of conceptual thinking has been done by any honourable member opposite since 1983 after the debacle of 1980-81. They are no better equipped now to run wages than they were in 1981. The fact is that if they cannot run wages they cannot run the Australian economy. Any party which says, `We cannot run wages' is saying to the Australian public, `We cannot run the Australian economy'. We have shown that we are the only party in Australia capable of running wages policy. That means that we are the only party capable of running the Australian economy.

Wages growth has run at about 6.5 to 6.75 per cent through the last 12 months, in the face of inordinately high economic activity. That would have burst out into a wages explosion in the hands of a Liberal government. Yet the Opposition's sole policy is that it would pay wage increases related to productivity. If productivity is running even at the current trend rate of 1 1/2 per cent, how would the Opposition believe that the unions and the work force of this country would accept a 1 1/2 per cent wages increase when inflation is running at 7 per cent and the market would be paying something like 12 per cent or 15 per cent? That is simply a prescription for a wage breakout-a wage explosion followed by a recession. No matter what gloss members opposite seek to put on it, in terms of their own indolence since 1983 not one person in the Federal Opposition has come up with a wages structure which will deal with the realities of the Australian labour market. They are no better equipped eight years later to deal with a strong economy and wages policy than they were in 1980-81.

Having wrecked the economy in 1981 and 1982, the person who presided over the wrecking, the Leader of the Opposition, wants to present himself now as the person who can best wreck it twice. He is saying, `Please elect me; we have a superior policy'. But when we ask, `What is the key policy on running the key determinant of costs in the economy?'-that is wages-his answer is: `Well, we'll pay wage increases related to productivity'. Everyone in Australian business, everyone in the markets, knows that the Opposition does not have a wages policy. What members opposite will see on Wednesday night is a wages policy-like they have seen for six earlier years-which will give us moderate wages growth right through the course of this year through the highest level of economic activity we have seen in eight or nine years.

The shadow spokesman asks puerile questions on wages policy. I know he has met Bill Kelty in airport terminals; he has told me about the conversations. He tore the shadow Minister to pieces; he made wallpaper out of him when he came up with this appalling prescription for wages policy.

—The Minister for Community Services and Health has no doubt seen the statement by Professor Ian Gust, his senior scientific and medical adviser on acquired immune deficiency syndrome, with which I wholeheartedly agree, namely, that AIDS education should place more emphasis on education for groups at high risk of contracting the disease. Does he agree with me that money is wasted on discouraging heterosexual vaginal intercourse by vastly exaggerating the risk of contracting AIDS by that pastime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of Professor Gust's comments on the AIDS education strategy. First, these remarks should be seen in the context of the comprehensive review of AIDS policy which is now being undertaken as we develop the AIDS White Paper. I think it is important to quote what Professor Gust said rather than what he was interpreted as saying. Professor Gust was reported in the Australian as having said:

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst I strongly believe that we should be educating the entire community about risks, I do think it is important that we put priority in our educational messages on those people who are at greatest risk of being infected.

That statement clearly reflects the AIDS education strategy of this Government, which is based on the advice of the Australian National Council on AIDS. While there has been a number of general awareness campaigns on AIDS-and I am very pleased with the response to these campaigns-most of the AIDS education campaigns have been directed or targeted at specific groups. —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The environmental consequences associated with the use of fossil fuel and nuclear fission are increasingly a source of concern and clearly alternative energy sources require our attention and support. Is the Minister aware of a recent article, in the 4 February edition of the New Scientist, which describes the use of so-called `hot rocks' beneath the earth's surface to produce plentiful power? Can he indicate the suitability of Australia for such geothermal energy production and the status of any research or investigation in this respect being carried out in this country?

—Resource surveys carried out in Australia indicate that there are only modest prospects for exploitation of hot dry rock-HDR-geothermal energy, and Australia is not active in this field. However, my Department maintains a watching brief on overseas developments. A number of technical problems remain to be resolved before HDR power plants are commercialised. Present indications from UK research are that it would not be cost-competitive with coal fired power stations in Australia. Currently the best prospects for geothermal-based electricity in Australia are in communities with access to hot artesian bore water which would otherwise depend on high cost electricity provided by diesel generators. With national energy research, development and demonstration program-NERDDP-support totalling some $700,000, an Alice Springs company, Enreco Pty Ltd, has developed heat engine technology ideally suited to Australia's geothermal resources and has installed this technology at Mulka Station in South Australia and is installing a second larger unit at Birdsville. But, by and large, all the research we do indicates that there are very limited applications for hot dry rock technology.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is the Minister aware that a number of community hospitals in Victoria are faced with closure and will be unable to maintain essential health services? Will the Minister, in consultation with his Victorian counterpart health Minister, approve the reclassification of beds so that public patients can be accepted by the bush nursing hospital system and that private funds are able to meet the insurance requirements of all clients?

—I point out to the questioner that the prime responsibility for bush hospitals in Victoria is with the Victorian Government, which it accepts. The Government has of course worked with Victorian governments over recent years in developing programs for some of those small bush hospitals. —I direct a question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. In the light of the most recent in a series of safety-related incidents involving United Airlines and the growing public concern about safety deficiencies following the deregulation of the airline industry in the United States, can the Minister assure the House that deregulation of airlines in Australia will not prejudice safety standards for airlines operating in and out of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the honourable member for Stirling and the House that the Government will not be deregulating safety. We have, of course, announced that there will be a cessation of economic regulation of domestic aviation from October 1990, but this does not mean in any way that the Government will withdraw from or lessen the effectiveness of safety regulation. On the contrary, we have taken some steps to try to ensure that our very satisfactory safety record is even further enhanced. A comprehensive review of the safety regulatory framework to streamline and simplify safety requirements and their administration has been commissioned. The first report has been presented and accepted in principle. A further report is expected later this year.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the United Airlines incidents, I should say that all international airlines conducting services into Australia are from countries which are contracting states of the International Civil Aviation Organisation. Each of these countries has an aviation regulatory authority responsible for ensuring the safety and airworthiness of aircraft registered there. By international agreement, the home country remains responsible for these matters even when the aircraft is overseas. The Australian Civil Aviation Authority therefore does not undertake any checks on international airlines and no other country undertakes checks on Qantas. However, the Australian Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) is involved in the investigation of incidents to foreign aircraft which occur in Australia. In this regard, I should say that that Bureau is investigating the incident involving United Airlines last Saturday in which one of its B747 aircraft was involved in a landing incident at Sydney which allegedly resulted in damage to the undercarriage and a wing. As soon as this BASI investigation has been completed, any action identified as necessary will be taken by the Australian authorities in relation to Australian registered aircraft.

The honourable member's question seeks an assurance that we will not in any way prejudice safety standards. I can assure the honourable member for Stirling that that is certainly the case. The actions taken by the Government in respect of economic regulation will ensure a more satisfactory domestic aviation industry. There will be no diminution in safety; indeed, that should be further enhanced.

—I draw to the attention of the Minister for Social Security recently released information on labour market movements. Can the Minister inform the House of recent trends and the number of people receiving unemployment benefit? Can he also indicate whether there has been an increase in the length of time people remain on unemployment benefit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is not irrelevant to the question previously answered by the Treasurer. Since 1983 there has been quite a remarkable decline in the number of people on unemployment benefit-from 627,000 to 470,000 in May last year and 407,000 in November 1988. In the 12 months to the end of March the number of people on benefit had fallen by 80,000. From time to time comment is made, sometimes by members of the Opposition, on the duration of unemployment benefit. It is sometimes said that, during the period that we have been in government, that duration has increased.

ANSWER.PARA: While there is some truth in that assertion I think it is interesting to look at the rate of fall-off of people on the benefit for various durations. For example, over the period November 1986 to November 1988 the decline in the number of people on the benefit was of the order of 23.5 per cent-nearly a quarter. The figure has fallen by 26.4 per cent for those on benefit for under six months duration and by 27.8 per cent for those on benefit for a duration of over six to 12 months. As we go into the longer durations we have a slower rate of decline. For example, for 12 to 24 months the reduction has been 18 per cent and for two years and over the figure has come down 16.3 per cent. While the average may see some increase, in all categories up to five years there has been a significant reduction in the number of people on unemployment benefit, particularly over the past two years. This Government's success in employment is reflected on the other side in the decreasing number of people on unemployment benefits.

Let me mention just one other statistic which I think is relevant. In 1983 a person who was unemployed for more than three months had a one in four chance of remaining unemployed for 12 months or more. Today that figure is down to one in eight and, of course, it is still rising.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The impact of high inflation, low productivity, high taxes and high interest rates under the Hawke/Keating Government on Australian living standards.
I call upon those members who approved of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition puts before the House this matter of public importance because not only have we had a great deal of material fed out on the wage-tax deal but also we foreshadow an approach in critique in regard to Wednesday's statement. Let it be known bluntly and to the point that the so-called wage-tax deal of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is nothing but a hoax. It will not deliver substantial improvements in living standards. It will in fact fuel inflation because wage increases under award restructuring are not expected even by the Treasurer to be offset by productivity improvements.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that Australians deserve an increase in real take home pay. Living standards have never been so depressed as a consequence of deliberate government policy as under this Government. Australians have been held hostage to fortune under the high inflation and high interest rates of the Government. The essential elements of the Government's wage-tax deal have been leaked to the press during the past couple of weeks and it is clear that the Treasurer has been rolled by the trade union leadership. I say that because in his address to the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) in September last year the Treasurer promised:
The wage-tax trade-off we will implement will secure a further fall in inflation to around 3 to 4 per cent in 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not another broken promise.

—That is right. To keep the promise the Treasurer needed zero across the board wage increases, and that was never on. It is now obvious that the Government's wage-tax trade-off will lead to higher inflation in 1990 and possibly even in 1991. His statement to EPAC was therefore downright misleading. There was no way that the Treasurer could get what he needed from the trade union leadership to keep his promise on inflation. This was a crucial failure by the Treasurer. He has now been forced to negotiate a wage-tax agreement which will fuel inflation and therefore provide for increases in tax revenue through bracket creep.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take a brief look at the wage-tax trade-off from the perspective of average Australian families, which have never had to cope with the difficulties imposed on them as a consequence of the delinquency of a government such as the one today. The Government is offering a tax cut of about $20 a week. This is not even enough to reimburse taxpayers for bracket creep since the tax summit in 1985, but worse is to come next year. Next year the Treasurer will claw back part of the tax cut as he taxes the wage increases granted under the guise of award restructuring. To add insult to injury, at the same time prices will rise during the next 12 months and will probably wipe out the increase in wages next year. Remember, all this will happen with the background of a forecast of inflation in the last Budget by the Treasurer of 4.5 per cent for this year. Even the Treasurer has admitted that award restructuring will not deliver a rise in productivity sufficient to justify the across the board wage increases demanded by the trade union leadership.

The Treasurer has been trying to create the myth-he sought to do so again at Question Time today-that under the Opposition's industrial relations policy wage increases would be limited to about 1.5 per cent per annum. To put it bluntly, this is absolute rubbish. Either he does not understand our policy or, more likely, he is being deliberately misleading. Of course, under Labor's centralised and rigid wage fixing system, the Government and the trade union leadership have delivered productivity increases which have not even averaged one per cent per annum during the last few years. Australia's productivity increases are abysmal.

In contrast, we are putting before the Australian people a program which will carry forth the deregulatory element that is required to make Australia competitive. Our policy provides for wages and working conditions to be settled at the industry and enterprise level. In a decentralised system it is in the interests of employees and employers to agree upon working conditions and wages which are productivity-based. Indeed, in those few instances where enterprise level bargaining has in fact occurred recently, in spite of the Government and in spite of the trade union leadership, the productivity increases are reported to be substantial. The bottom line is that the Labor Government and the trade union leadership simply cannot deliver the increases in productivity which are necessary to raise real wages and hence living standards. At the same time, they cannot deliver cuts in taxes which will provide a sustainable increase in real take home pay.
As we all know, a taxpayer on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children will be $58 a week worse off in June 1989 than he was when the Hawke Government was elected in March.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Fifty-eight dollars a week would be required to be paid-this is the measure of the task-to a person on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children if we were to return that family to a position of having the same real disposable income as it would have had when the Hawke Government was elected. After the Treasurer's wage-tax deal this family will still be about $50 a week worse off. This does not even take into account the increase in the home loan interest rate. Since December 1988 mortgage interest rates have risen to 16 per cent. This means nearly $100 a week extra for average home loan repayments.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened carefully to what the Treasurer had to say when he was seeking to argue-I think these were the words he used-that a party without a wages policy is a party with no economic policy at all. We have a wages policy. We not only have a wages policy. We have the only relevant wages policy for the future of this country. In determining who is the one best fitted to make Australia more productive and competitive we cannot continue with the corporate type deals and fixes that go on between the Government and the trade union movement in Canberra. What earthly relationship has the determination of the wage of a man on the factory floor to the tax the Treasurer will take from him? Wages are not determined by some government plotting a tax mechanism. The whole wage-tax deal is irrelevant to what a man ought to get. Rather, one relates what that person ought to get to the job he does.

This Government, possessed with a corporate notion and possessed with a need to have a fix and a deal between itself and the trade union movement, cannot see that the essential drive for the future is labour market deregulation if this country is to become competitive and, in fact, if we are in an overall sense, with a responsible fiscal policy in place, to be tackling inflation. Wage increases that are essentially unrelated to productivity, as are the ones that will be forecast by the Treasurer on Wednesday night, are wage increases that give no justice at all in terms of any real lift in living standards. We will hear the hyperbole and the nonsense that is spoken. But the truth has dawned on the overwhelming majority of Australians, for they no longer accept the word of this man who is the Treasurer.

The Treasurer is detached from the mainstream of the Australian community. I have said it time and again and I will say it again: in any future electoral contest-there clearly will be one in the course of the next few months-one should look at the way that this man campaigns in trying to get everybody's vote. He will not go out on the street; he will not go into the pubs; he will not go into the nursing homes; he will not mix with any people. In fact, when he is travelling he is hiding behind tinted glass so that we cannot see him. Frankly, it is not because he does not want anyone to see him; it is because he does not want to see anyone. The only way he will communicate with the people is by going into the antiseptic atmosphere of a press conference and talking to journalists in hyperbole about the way he sees Australia developing. His ideal notion for the future of this country is the antithesis of ours. He has lost interest in delivering real and substantial increases in living standards. Any person listening to this broadcast knows that people are in an infinitely worse position today than they were before the election of the Hawke Government. They have great fears about the future of this nation.

This Government has limited economic policies. It failed to implement effective fiscal reform in its last two Budgets. It has failed to introduce effective micro-economic reform. Those failures have meant an undue reliance on monetary policy and high interest rates. Let me remind the House that the hallmark of the third term of the Hawke Government was to be micro-economic reform. It has been 18 months since that was mooted and we have heard nothing but talk-inquiries and committees. Albeit that micro-economic reform was to be a central feature of the statement on Wednesday night, it cannot even be included then, notwithstanding the receipt of the Inter-State Commission's report on the waterfront that was delivered to the Government last week. The Treasurer of this nation is now backed into a corner. His options are gone. The rhetoric is there, but those levers we heard about that can so oft be pulled by the Government are being pulled in only one way: on monetary policy. Devoid of options, therefore, the Treasurer is left solely with the one-dimensional economic policy of forcing up interest rates.

I said earlier that the wage-tax deal is an outright failure. It has failed because it will not significantly increase living standards and it will not break the back of inflation. One cannot mask, through verbiage, the depression in living standards that the Treasurer's Government has forced on Australians. In short, if we listen to this man, we listen to someone who paints a false picture. He says to the people that the wage-tax deal is an incomes policy of great merit. It is an incomes policy that will fuel inflation and further retard the living standards of Australians.

We do not want the continuation of some one-dimensional program under this Government. What is needed in Australia is a coordinated set of economic programs. That means tighter fiscal policy and an industrial relations system focusing on the industry and enterprise level, with wage increases related to productivity improvements. When we have those two settings in place we can have a steadier monetary policy to reduce inflation gradually. The Government cannot do that, nor can it take the additional measures that are needed within a coordinated set of programs: namely, a real push on deregulation, micro-economic reform and a schedule of privatisation.

All these measures, if implemented, would change the face of the Australian economy. The Opposition has these policies: responsible fiscal policies and wages policies whereby wage increases are related to productivity increases. With those settings in place we need a steady monetary policy to reduce inflation, a push on deregulation, effective micro-economic reform and a whole schedule of bodies to be privatised. These are the programs that would be pursued by the Opposition to bring about not only a competitive Australia but also the increase in living standards that is so sorely required by Australians today.

Treasurers essentially have two duties. They are there to lift living standards. They are not elected for their own benefit, to swan around the world, to buy antiques, to glory in the praise of their colleagues. They are there to lift living standards, through effective economic programs, and to govern in the better interests of Australia generally by forging a stronger, more competitive Australia. This Treasurer has failed on both counts. We, however, with our more coordinated programs, will turn that around. We will make the effort that is required to make Australia more productive and more competitive. There fore we will be able to deliver sustainable improvements in living standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--

I do not think the Australian public has any doubts about how the Treasurer is performing in Australia today because his message is coming through loud and clear. It is very obvious that, after eight years in opposition, honourable members opposite have still not developed any of those policy positions.

On fiscal policy there is a division between the honourable member for Kooyong and the honourable member for Wentworth. Quite clearly, they cannot decide whether they should be tougher or softer than this Government, or whether they should have high interest rates. The honourable member for Wentworth continually makes long speeches at public functions and puts out long press releases. In all of those press releases, he has always called for higher interest rates and tighter monetary policy, yet the shadow Treasurer makes statements in the House which clearly indicate that he is in direct line with the Treasurer in relation to fiscal policy.

Let us consider the wording of the matter of public importance. The shadow Treasurer spoke of the impact of high inflation, low productivity, high taxes and high interest rates on Australian living standards. Let us do some comparisons in relation to these matters. The comments about high inflation come from members of a former government who, when the Australian public made the judgment that they were incompetent and threw then out, had inflation running at double digit figures-at 11.5 per cent. As the Treasurer in an answer at Question Time today said, we have had inflation down as low as 5 per cent since coming to government and it is now between 6 per cent or 7 per cent, depending on the figures we look at. That is a marvellous achievement, considering what the Government has had to face up to in the world economic situation and the income of this nation.

Let us look at the policies of the previous Government. The people of Australia need to be aware of them because they have to make a judgment very soon, as the honourable member for Kooyong said. Some time in the next eight or nine months we have to go to the people in an election. Is the Opposition still pushing for fixed exchange rates, or is that no longer the policy? That was the policy in place when honourable members opposite destroyed the economy of Australia. When they were last in power they destroyed manufacturing industry. They closed down industries in every capital city in Australia. They destroyed employment; 180,000 people in the manufacturing metals industry alone were thrown out of work in a very short time. Exports were slack because of that high exchange rate. Our exporting industries could not compete.

When we were in opposition listening to the so-called economic policies of those opposite, we heard how the resources boom would pull Australia out. We were going to sell so much coal and iron ore on the world market and there would be such a boom and so much money would flow into Australia that we needed to buy imports to balance that flow of money into Australia. The conservatives of this nation, with a direct policy, set about creating the exchange rate in such a way that they destroyed the economy of Australia and brought it to an absolute halt. We have still not heard any different policies from the Opposition in this regard. The Opposition's policies have destroyed much of Australia.

Let us look at some of the Government's actions since that time and what it has had to do. First, we had to control the inflation rate, which was running at 11 1/2 per cent. But at the same time we had given a commitment that we would get people back to work. This required completely different policies from those which had been followed by the conservatives at that time-policies that they still will not talk about today. Our major initiative was, of course, the floating of the exchange rate. This was a major change in the economic development of this country. We had to reduce government spending and we have been extremely successful. For all the cries from the Opposition benches and from conservatives in this country, those people cannot come forward and argue with any substance that this Government has not been extremely successful in controlling public sector spending, because the evidence is there-it is on the record. Today we are looking at a surplus in excess of $5 billion as against a projected deficit of $9.6 billion when we came to power. The record is there for the Australian people to make their judgment.

Let us look at the other major factor in inflation-the wages policy, on which the honourable member for Kooyong spoke for 15 seconds. Before this Government came to office, whilst it was doing its homework when in opposition-something which this Opposition is not capable of-it set about discussing the accord with the trade union movement in Australia, that great bulk of people who put together a lot of Australia's wealth. It came up with a proposal which has stood the test of time. That accord was based on the Australian community being prepared to play its part on wage levels in order to put Australia back on its feet. Nobody can point the finger at the trade union movement of this nation and say that over the past five or six years it has not played its part. Those people are now looking forward to Wednesday night for some benefits flowing from their actions over the past four or five years. I do not believe that without the accord any government in Australia could have faced up to the collapse in commodity prices that this nation had to face during the period of this Government. We copped that on top of the problems that we inherited from the Opposition.

The accord with the trade union movement became extremely central to how not only this Government but also this nation had to perform in order to recover from the inept policies of our predecessors and from a collapse in commodity prices around the world which slashed the Australian economy and the ability of Australians to buy goods overseas. The accord certainly stood up to that. In the meantime, while all this was happening our policies were such that we were able to create 1.3 million new jobs in Australia-more than two-thirds of them being permanent, full time jobs-putting back to work the people of Australia who had lost their jobs under our predecessors and putting into jobs a lot of our young people who needed to get into the work force. We were able to do two things at one time.

After eight years the Opposition still has no wages policy. Members of the Opposition come into this place and spend 15 seconds talking about wages based on productivity. What about wages based on consultation and on other policies? What about wages based on education for the future and wages as part of the economy, not just part of the profit sector? I believe that this Government has been very successful in those areas and, at the head of that, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer have led the way. To hear the honourable member for Kooyong speaking today one would think that it all happened by chance and that there was something wrong with the structure which is now in place.

Today the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in answer to a question, gave the House the figures for unemployment benefit recipients-down from 627,000 in 1983 to 407,000 in November 1988, and down by 80,000 in the last eight months for which figures have been kept. Once again this is a clear indicator that the position for the great bulk of Australians is better today than it has been for a considerable time.

The Opposition has no policy on tax. It is bringing forward this matter of public importance because, on Wednesday night, the Treasurer will deliver a very comprehensive package in relation to what is going to be the taxation structure of this nation for several years to come. Let us look at what the Opposition had to offer when it was in government. It had personal tax rates running at 60 per cent, and 66 per cent at one stage. The Opposition claims that it wants to have industry and business operating. In pre-Hawke Government time business, companies and people receiving dividends were paying up to 78 per cent tax on their returns. That is another area of reform introduced by this Government. Today Australia has tax imputation and company tax at 39 per cent as part of the ongoing package. With tax imputation there is a real incentive for Australians to get in and create wealth. One cannot create wealth unless the incentive is there.

Honourable members hear from the Opposition about incentives. Where was the incentive from the conservative parties when this country had tax rates of 66 per cent, with companies paying tax at that rate plus the tax on dividends which came to a total of 78 per cent? Members of the Opposition have the cheek to come into this House and talk about incentives. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition spoke about the impact of the Government's policies on living standards in Australia. I shall only point to the last five years in relation to this matter.

There are difficulties and the Government has admitted the difficulties. These have come from two sources-first, the ineptitude of the former Government and, secondly, the collapse in commodity prices. It is now two years since commodity prices started to turn around. This country is now starting to earn income. One thing that is overlooked by many in the debates is that a lot of the wealth that has come into Australia over the last couple of years has come in through the export sector, through improved exports of wool, wheat and cotton. A lot of that money comes straight into the hands of the people who export in Australia. They have it in their possession tax free until such time as they make their first taxation payments, which are due on 10 April, today. Tax day is the day for a lot of wool cheques.

There is a massive amount of money in the system in relation to the income improvement. That income improvement adds to the flow of money in the system, and no-one denies that. It would be irresponsible to add to that to the extent that one would blow inflation right out the window, so there has to be a time lag in relation to the flow of that money through the system. The benefits that will now accrue to the wage and salary earners of Australia are coming about because of their patience in relation to this matter. They have displayed absolute responsibility to the nation. They have played their part. They have not gone out on the open market demanding wage increases, as members of the Opposition have suggested they would. They have not used their muscle power to demand the wages that they could have gained in the so-called free enterprise approach of the Opposition. They have been responsible because of their relationship with this Government.

The responsibility of wage and salary earners is to be rewarded by their share of the wealth that has been generated. It can only be transferred from one generating sector to another by a series of policy processes, which can only be delivered by a Labor government. So when the House hears proposals about living standards in Australia such as it is hearing today from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, it should keep in mind the fact that in the 15 minutes he spoke he never dwelt on the subject. He spent less than one minute on the major issues of important policy. He spent no time whatever telling the Australian people what the intentions of the Opposition are. He had very little of substance to criticise what the Government has done. It will be interesting to hear what the honourable member for Wentworth has to say in contradicting the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, no doubt as soon as he gets to his feet.

We on this side of the House are proud of our Government. We are proud of our record and we are proud of our Treasurer. We look forward on Wednesday night to what can only be another step in the process of reconstruction of this nation and to another step within the accord of the trade union movement with this Government. The Government is part of that accord. The Australian economy will be put on its feet. I am sure that in these circumstances, in the election period that we are approaching, this Government will probably for the first time in history be a Labor government that not only has rectified the economy of Australia-a Labor government did it after the last war and at the depression time-but also is given credit for it by the people of Australia and will be given the opportunity to see that the benefits of reconstructed Australia are spread across all Australians and are not grabbed by one sector as would occur if the conservatives on the Opposition benches today were given the opportunity. I believe in the Australian people's intelligence and I believe that they will sustain a Labor government.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NATIONAL BIOLOGICAL STANDARDS LABORATORY, SYMONSTON, AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of the National Biological Standards Laboratory, Symonston, ACT.

The proposed work recommended by the Public Works Committee is for the construction of the National Biological Standards Laboratory (NBSL) for the Department of Community Services and Health. The proposal involves the construction of a single complex at Symonston in the Australian Capital Territory to accommodate the facilities and functions of the NBSL, which currently operates out of some 18 separate buildings in nine locations in Canberra and two in Melbourne. Much of the existing accommodation is leased and many of the facilities are in poor condition, inappropriately located, cramped and requiring substantial repairs and maintenance expenditure.

The administrative and operational difficulties and cost inefficiencies of these arrangements are significant and the provision of up to date purpose built facilities is essential. The NBSL encompasses three branches of the Therapeutics Division of the Department of Community Services and Health and administers the Government's therapeutic goods program. This seeks to safeguard the Australian community in relation to the quality, safety and effectiveness of therapeutic goods and is achieved through: evaluation of pharmaceuticals, biologicals and therapeutic devices; laboratory analysis of therapeutic goods; inspection of Australian therapeutic goods manufacturers; monitoring the effectiveness of drugs and devices; development of relevant standards; operation of the national therapeutic goods register; provision of specialised advice, training and education; monitoring drug information; and import and export controls.

Each year some 40 to 50 new prescription drugs are evaluated and approved for marketing, adding to the 18,000 or so medicines and similar number of therapeutic devices on the Australian market. The importance of these activities to the Australian community is evident. In 1986-87 over one-third of manufacturers inspected by NBSL were assessed as having less than acceptable levels of compliance with the codes of good manufacturing practice and approximately 10 per cent of samples analysed failed to comply with specifications. In addition, recalls of unsatisfactory products number about 140 per year.

The proposed works consist of a single laboratory building totalling approximately 17,900 square metres in area, and include the conversion of an existing building for the breeding of laboratory animals. This building was originally opened in 1975 to permit the testing of brucella vaccine, but is no longer required for that purpose. The new laboratory building will be a two-storey structure, in the form of two linear wings linked at the centre by an enclosed common space and is sited to make use of the preparatory siteworks undertaken in 1980-81 for a previous larger proposal. That proposal, which was referred to the Public Works Committee in 1979 and subsequently approved by Parliament, was deferred as a cost cutting measure in 1981 by the former Government.

The new building will include biological, chemical and engineering laboratories, as well as staff amenities, library, workshops, storage areas and office accommodation for associated administrative and scientific support staff. It will incorporate all the complex services normally associated with laboratories and will include specific features to ensure biological security and the safe disposal of wastes. The estimated cost of the proposal as presented to the Public Works Committee was $51.4m at July 1988 prices and, subject to approval, works will commence shortly with the conversion of the existing brucella building.

As is the case with almost all major Commonwealth building projects, construction work will be performed by the use of private contracting firms, subcontractors and suppliers. Completion of the works is expected towards the end of 1992. I thank the Committee for its prompt report and commend the motion to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF SHELL FILLING FACILITY FOR ST MARYS MUNITIONS FILLING FACTORY, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of a shell filling facility for St Marys Munitions Filling Factory, New South Wales.

The St Marys Munitions Filling Factory is located about 45 kilometres west of Sydney and is one of the three main explosives manufacturing factories operated by the Department of Defence. It is the only facility in Australia capable of filling shells and is used to load shells from 76-millimetre calibre up to five inches with high explosive. The factory site consists of approximately 800 buildings made up of explosives processing buildings, storage magazines, support buildings and engineering services.

The proposed work now before the House is for the construction of a new shell filling facility at the factory. Within this proposed facility, shell cases will be filled with high explosives such as TNT or a mixture of TNT and other explosives. This is a specialist operation involving a casting process in which the explosive is melted, poured into the shell case and allowed to solidify under controlled conditions. The existing shell filling facility at St Marys has been operating on an almost continuous basis since 1958 and, as a result of high usage, general wear and corrosion, the exisiting plant has reached the end of its economic life. In addition, fume, dust and noise levels exceed current regulatory standards.

The St Marys factory has an excellent safety record and in fact has the highest rating of any Australian Government industrial organisation in the National Safety Council of Australia's five-star safety management system. The proposed new shell filling facility and plant will provide a safer and more efficient working environment for employees. It is anticipated that both labour and maintenance costs will be significantly reduced. The proposed work comprises a new process building which contains shell preparation, fill and probing section and a shell finishing section; associated engineering services and site works; earth mounds for safety protection; and a trade waste treatment system.

The estimated cost of the proposed shell filling facility as recommended by the Committee is $7.7m at April 1988 prices. This cost updated to March 1989 prices is $8.25m. A process plant estimated to cost approximately $6m will be installed during the construction phase. This plant will meet the current and expected production requirements of the Department of Defence for both medium and large calibre shells.

Subject to the approval of the House to proceed, it is intended that the first tenders will be called in mid-1989. Construction is expected to be completed by mid-1991 and up to 50 people will be employed on site during the peak construction period. I thank the Committee for its consideration and support for this proposal and I commend the motion to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUREAU OF STATISTICS AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In another place a Bill for an Act to provide for voluntary answers to statistical surveys and for all surveys of that nature, save for the census itself, was negatived on a tied vote. A new Bill for an Act to amend the Australian Bureau of Statistics Act 1975 to provide for parliamentary supervision of the collection of information for statistical purposes was then proposed and passed. Of course, it has now been reported to the chamber and I am pleased to have the opportunity of moving that the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to allow for parliamentary scrutiny and, if necessary, rejection of statistical proposals within five sitting days of their tabling in both Houses of Parliament. Under present arrangements, if the Australian Statistician wishes to make a compulsory survey, he is required to table his proposal in both Houses. There is currently no provision to reject or vary the proposals. The Statistician did not table the present household expenditure survey, which is a compulsory one and thus differs in a most significant way from the previous surveys, which were voluntary. One can only surmise that the reason was to keep the increased size, inquisitiveness and expansion of the survey from the view of the Parliament.

The current household expenditure survey has caused great contention and concern in the community. It is no exaggeration to say that there has been harassment of the community, despite denials by the Statistician. The Statistician is asking people to disclose intimate details of a most personal nature of their household income and expenditure, information that could not possibly be of value for determining the consumer price index, average weekly earnings and pension increases. Information such as the size and nature of bank loans, the collateral offered for them, access to bank accounts, access to financial institutions and other such information up to and including production of income tax returns has been sought. So much for having a privacy Bill-that was very much a matter for debate in this chamber in a recent session-to protect tax files and, in many respects, to ensure that tax file numbers served only the purpose for which the legislation intended them. This is being circumvented by the Statistician who now, under the survey arrangements, can ask for one's tax return.

The Australian Statistician has become far too aggressive and assertive and has disregarded the parliamentary process. He decided not to table the proposals for household expenditure surveys and yet wanted to compel answers from people on the grounds that the survey was no different from previous ones. This is patently ridiculous and has been admitted by officers from the Australian Bureau of Statistics to be so in the Estimates Committee in another place, because other surveys were voluntary and if this one is compulsory that significant difference is clearly disclosed.
This Bill will allow for parliamentary scrutiny of the survey proposals and their acceptance or rejection. Acceptance will give the proposals the authority of parliamentary scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —In taking advantage of the broad nature of debate allowed on the Appropriation Bills, I wish to say something about the coalition's view of the economic significance of the small business sector. I do not think that many people would argue with the proposition that both the Liberal and the National parties regard the small business sector as the locomotive of the Australian economy. We recognise that small business generates about 40 per cent of this nation's value added and that it is providing an increasing share of employment in Australia-that currently more than 50 per cent of all jobs in this country are provided by the small business sector.

SPEECH.PARA: I also contend that over the next decade or so small business will continue to grow in its importance to the Australian economy. There are a couple of reasons for this. First, small business has enormous advantages of flexibility over its big business counterparts and flexibility in business management will be a fundamental hallmark of a successful business over the next decade or so. That is because the rapid change in technology will require flexibility and because the community's tastes nowadays are changing much more rapidly than they did, for example, in the period immediately following the Second World War.

I think small business will also grow significantly in importance because of its capacity to improve productivity beyond levels which are usually achieved in the big business sector. It has been very interesting to look at the way big companies in Italy and Japan have subcontracted work out to small firms because they find that small firms have a greater level of productivity than is possible in a big enterprise. There are many logical reasons for that. Small firms are more personal: people know each other better and consequently there are fewer industrial relations problems in the main. Also, because of the use of technology-for example, computer work stations-people can work in their own homes in order to assist big businesses and therefore are working in a more pleasant, relaxed and personal work environment than would be the case on a large shop floor. Consequently, rates of productivity are very much higher. For those two reasons-flexibility and productivity-the small business sector will continue to grow in importance in this country and will do so perhaps quite dramatically over the next decade or so.

That is a matter that will not give a great deal of comfort to the Hawke Labor Government. On the other hand, that Government will not need to worry too much over the next decade because it will not be in office. These factors I have mentioned will not sit comfortably with the Australian Labor Party's philosophy or ideology because it fundamentally believes in the concept of the corporate state-to put it colloquially, in doing things at the big end of town. Big business, big government and big unions make up the troika which is very much the hallmark of the way this Government has operated. Consequently, that enormously productive, exciting and vibrant small business sector of our economy is almost ignored in the day to day administrative decisions and policy making processes of the present Government.

This Government will say that it has done two things: it has appointed a Minister for small business in the form of the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones); and it has set up the inquiry by the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology into problems facing small business, although this inquiry has actually been set up by the Parliament, not the Government. I would contend that first of all the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) is little more than a token Minister in that portfolio. He is a man whose interests range very widely in the scientific community but he has been passive in his involvement in small business issues. The Government needs to have a small business awareness program within the public sector so that government departments, when formulating advice for Ministers, and Ministers, when making decisions, can take into consideration the implications of those decisions on the small business sector of our economy. The theory of having a Minister for small business is that he or she is able to range widely over government decisions or proposed decisions to ensure that they will not be at the very least inimical to the interests of the small business sector. But that simply has not happened. The reality is that the present Minister, whether he is interested in the portfolio or not, simply does not have the clout in the Government or the resources within his Department to have very much idea of what is going on at all through the vast network of government.

It is important that in the years ahead, when we on this side of the House become the Government, we take into consideration the need to ensure that the public sector is fully aware of the needs and the concerns of that productive sector of our economy, the small business sector. The parliamentary inquiry which is currently taking place has had an enormous brief and has travelled all over Australia talking to different small business groups and small businesses themselves. But the fact is that the Committee is monstrously understaffed. It simply does not have the resources to conclude an inquiry which is sufficiently educated or sufficiently well thought through. That is not a reflection on the hardworking members of the Committee; it is simply a statement of fact about the resources that the Parliament has allocated to that Committee.

There is a crying need for this Parliament and for the Government to have a better understanding of the needs and problems of small business. There are groups that work very hard to make sure the Parliament understands the concerns of small business, and I mention in particular the work of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia and the Australian Small Business Association. They have done an enormous amount of work with very limited resources, as they continually point out, to make sure that we in this Parliament understand their concerns. The fact is that we need to have a clearer view at government level than is currently the case.

Let us look at some of the specific concerns that the small business community has and which need to be addressed by the Government if it is try to get this country out of the economic morass that it is currently in. First and foremost, the small business community in this country is concerned about costs. If its cost structure bears no relationship to that of small business or any businesses in other parts of the world, then Australian small business will simply not be able to compete. The record on taxes over the past six years is, in the context of small business, a very sorry one. What can be described as a raft of anti-business taxes has been introduced. The notorious fringe benefits tax, with all the administration involved in adhering to its requirements, has done a great deal of damage to the small business community. It is so often forgotten that that tax has done a lot of damage to the small business community because the vocal voices of business are those of big business, and big business has had less difficulty with that tax than small firms have. It is not just because of the money that has been taken away from those firms by way of the fringe benefits tax; it is also because of the amount of time that must be spent actually administering that fearfully complicated tax.

The other tax which has discriminated so fiercely against small business is the capital gains tax. People on the other side of the House just do not seem to understand that the one thing small shopkeepers or small deli owners work for on their tiny incomes through the year is the prospect of selling that business at the end of the time they want to own it or at the end of their working lives and receiving some money from that which, in effect, will constitute their retirement package. Why on earth would anyone want to tax the money that those people have been able to accumulate through their own hard work? Why would a government want to tax the goodwill that a business has built up over many years of hard work? Yet that is what the capital gains tax has done. When we come to government we will abolish the capital gains tax and we will also get rid of Labor's fringe benefits tax. We will ensure that only rorts in that area are taxed and that we can cast aside the mass of administration and higher costs that have been imposed on small businesses over the past six years.

It is not as though after all these taxes have been introduced small business has received any compensating relief, which is the argument the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tries to put. It must be remembered also that the Government abolished the investment allowance, which was something that did give small business some assistance. The Government reduced the rate of company tax to 39 per cent. That is all very well for the person whose business is incorporated, but the rate of tax is not 39 per cent if one's business is not incorporated. The people who benefited-in so far as it can be argued that they benefited at all from that reduction in company tax-were the big businesses. Small businesses did not get that benefit if they were not incorporated. Big businesses, by their very nature are almost all-but not quite all-incorporated.

Small businesses pay the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. They pay a whole raft of new taxes on top of that, but they did not get the compensating reduction in company tax which went to the big end of town. That is highly insensitive and it shows once more that the Government is simply out of touch.

Let us look at the wholesale sales tax. Members of the Labor Party, when they were scurrying about in opposition in 1981-82, promised that a Labor government would extend the period of payment of the wholesale sales tax to ease the cash flow problems of small businesses. Six years on, there is silence; nothing has happened. The Government has not taken any action at all on timing of the payment of sales tax. For our side of the House, that is going to be an extremely important agenda item when we come into power.

What about the administration of the Australian Taxation Office? Its officers have gone out and harassed small business in this country. The office has worked on the basis that those small businesses it has decided to audit are guilty until they can prove themselves innocent. The Australian Taxation Office has created enormous inconvenience, enormous embarrassment and enormous cost to small business. It is an office which obviously has no sympathy for the real genius of our capitalist system, the heart of which is the small business sector.

When one looks at other aspects of economic management one comes of course to the one tool of economic management being used in recent years, that is, interest rates. The only tool of economic management that has been used for the last year at the very least, if not for longer, is interest rates. For small business they have increased by 33 per cent in the last 12 months. Honourable members should never forget that most small businesses do not have access to equity financing. Big businesses do, but not the small end of town. Small businesses have to go out and borrow money. The average small businesses have an overdraft limit of about $80,000 of working capital. On average they borrow about $60,000 of that $80,000 limit and they are paying today an interest rate of about 20 per cent on that money. Just over a year ago, in March last year, they were paying 15 per cent. The consequence, on the basis of those figures, is that the annual interest bill for those firms is now $12,000 and in March last year it was running at $9,000. That means that the average small business is paying about $250 a month in higher costs because the Government has used only one tool of economic management, that is, driving up interest rates.

The consequence of this is that small businesses are deferring capital expenditure, because loans are the major source of small business investment in capital. It is a shame-in fact, it is more than a shame: I suppose that is an understatement-that the Government has chosen that one instrument of economic policy which so fearfully discriminates against the small business sector. Small business is also being burdened with a mass of red tape. The House has already had a brief debate on Australian Bureau of Statistics surveys, which have compulsorily to be completed by small firms which might have only two or three people working in them. Small businesses have also to cope with a mass of tax forms. I mentioned the fringe benefits tax. A mass of tax forms have to be laboriously filled in. On top of that, State and local government regulations in many States are growing almost exponentially. I cannot see how small businesses will ever succeed if they have to spend as much time as they currently must simply on adhering to all that red tape that is being imposed on them from above, from Canberra and from some of the State parliaments.

Another major concern that I have, on top of the cost structure of small business, is the lack of concern in the Government and perhaps throughout the community for the concentration of market power in the hands of fewer and larger companies. If the Government wants to have in this country an effective capitalist system it has to have a competitive capitalist system. One thing that we on this side of the House will always oppose is the principle of monopoly capitalism. We do not believe in monopolies. We believe in competition. The instrument of competition that the Federal Parliament has created is the Trades Practices Act and its administrative body, the Trade Practices Commission. Yet the Trades Practices Commission has been hopelessly short of resources over the last few years. Between the 1980-81 financial year and the 1987-88 financial year, government outlays increased in real terms by 24 per cent, but outlays for Trade Practices Commission declined in real terms by 7 per cent. That is the priority the Government has given to a competitive marketplace.

More resources need to be provided to the Trade Practices Commission and more thought needs to be given to the operation of the Trade Practices Act to make sure that there are effective relationships in business and effective rules in business that provide for fair and reasonable competition. For example, where business leases are concerned there needs to be fair and reasonable competition so that big companies do not get special deals while small companies have to pay more. There needs to be fair and reasonable franchise arrangements too, which at least at the State level need to be carefully reconsidered. To those of us on this side of the House those are matters of very high priority.

When one looks at the consequences of the few issues that I have been able to raise in the time available to me-and there are many others I would like to have referred to-one can see that small business has been the big loser from the Hawke Government; and, because it has been the big loser, all Australians have been the big losers. Our exports have been big losers. Our housing policies have been big losers. The ordinary people in the community have seen their living standards decline because small business has not been able to perform effectively enough, so they are big losers as well. According to the latest figures available-which admittedly are not very late-provided by the Attorney-General's Department, bankruptcies are at a seven-year high. In the 1986-87 financial year, they increased by over 27 per cent and would surely have increased over the next financial year by a similar and very alarming proportion. A survey published last week by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures and the State Bank of New South Wales, taken of 503 companies in New South Wales, many of which were small, showed the most alarming results that I have seen from a survey of that kind for quite some time. The survey showed that there was a decline in export orders among those 503 companies to the lowest level in the five-year history of the survey.

This country has a balance of payments crisis, if the Government did not know it, and those companies are not able to export. They are not able to export because their cost structure is wrong and because this country does not have an effective competitive capitalist system. And, at the end of the day, we have a government which is arrogantly disregarding small business because it believes so passionately in its old friend the corporate state, including those at the big end of town, part of the mates network, the Alan Bonds and all those special people who mean so much to the Government, the big unions and of course big government itself. That is what the Government is about. When we on this side of the House come to power it will be goodbye to the corporate state.
