SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), on several occasions I heard him echoing one of the Opposition's favourite sayings these days-that the Labor Government has used only one instrument of economic policy, that is, monetary policy, and that if only the Government used the other two major legs of economic policy we would not have all the difficulties that we have today. I suspect that this is another example of the proof of a saying of H. L. Mencken that to every difficult problem there is a simple solution and it is always wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's claims that, if we could simply use fiscal and wages policy as well as monetary policy, all of the economic problems would be solved are plainly ridiculous. We simply have to look at the alternative wages policy which the Opposition is putting forward. I thought that the Opposition's wages policy was a free-for-all. The Opposition has been coming into this Parliament day after day saying that it is wrong for the Government to have a national wages system under which people have to go to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission at the central level and justify the wage increases that they are after. The Opposition has been saying that it was wrong for the Government to intervene in the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and stop the technicians getting payments which we thought were outside the wages system. The Opposition has been saying that it is wrong for the Government to interfere with Qantas Airways Ltd in determining the wages it pays its engineers because the Government believes it is important that there be no wages break-out at this time. The Opposition has been saying that there should be a free-for-all in wages. It is not putting up an alternative leg of economic policy in the wages area, that is for certain.

What about fiscal policy? What is the Opposition telling us about the third leg, about fiscal policy? I could have sworn that I heard the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) say that, in the coming election campaign, he will not need to detail any further budgetary cuts; that the Opposition's economic policies have been structured in such a way that it will not have to tell us where the cuts will be in the coming election campaign. So what is the difference between the Opposition's fiscal policy and this Government's fiscal policy? We are saying that we have cut as far as we can without hitting those low and middle income earners who are important to our country. Perhaps it is too hard for the Opposition to put forward policies on where it would cut Government expenditure. When the Opposition says that this Government concentrates only on one leg of economic policy-monetary policy-I wonder what its alternative is for wages and fiscal policy? As far as I can tell, it has no alternative policy in the fiscal or monetary area. Let us think back to the Fraser years when the present Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer. We did not have tight interest rates as we have today; we had crippling interest rates-interest rates that drove this economy into the worst recession that we have had since the Great Depression. So I wonder how many legs of policy the Leader of the Opposition used when he was the Treasurer back in the early 1980s.

This afternoon in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1988-89 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 I wish to cover a number of topics. The first area I wish to cover is the debate in the community about the foreign purchase of Australian land and Australian companies. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware that in September 1987 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced that the Government would introduce a ban on the foreign purchase of established residential real estate. That proposal is something which has my full support and, I would have thought, the support of all members of the Australian Parliament. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware of the massive increase in home prices, especially in Sydney, in most of the capital cities throughout our country in recent years. That has meant that it has become very difficult for young Australians to purchase their first homes. With the appreciation of currencies such as the yen it becomes very attractive for the citizens of some other countries to purchase attractive real estate in Sydney.

I suppose that in 1987 there was a concentration on the sale of very expensive, very valuable real estate sites around Sydney Harbour. But if the Australians at the top end of the market cannot buy very expensive homes around Sydney Harbour they get pushed down a little into the middle area of the market and those who used to be in the middle area get pushed down into a slightly lower area of the real estate market. The final result is that those at the bottom of the market, the battlers who are struggling to get their first homes, are the ones who are pushed aside. They are the ones who cannot afford to buy their homes. That is why I completely support this Government's legislation to implement that ban on the foreign purchase of established Australian residential real estate.

I am, therefore, disturbed with the Opposition's policy on this legislation. This legislation is now before the House to implement that ban. Let me quote from the contribution by Senator Messner, the Opposition spokesman on these matters in the Senate. In early March in his contribution to the second reading debate on the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill, Senator Messner made the following comment:
The Government was totally politically motivated in setting down this measure. We-
that is, the Opposition-

will be opposing in the committee stage those clauses in the Bill which seek to implement controls over residential real estate. That is consistent with the Liberal and National Parties' position. We have been exposing this issue since this policy was first announced in September 1987.

As the Treasurer pointed out in this House, I believe in early March, there is a bit of inconsistency within the Opposition parties on Senator Messner's position. There have been many statements by members of the Opposition, usually not in Canberra but back in their electorates, as to their own personal views on this legislation which the Government has introduced to ban the foreign purchase of established residential real estate. It is known that the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) has called for swift measures to alter foreign investment rules to require 51 per cent of Australian ownership. Senator Sheil is on the record as saying that foreign investment should be restricted to joint ventures with local companies. The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) has stated:
The current level of investment is a foreign land grab that is a threat to the freedom of Australians.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd), an office holder of the Opposition, is on record as calling for Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) thresholds to be made more restrictive. Even the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) has called for restraint on foreign investment in Australia. Certainly Opposition members, when they are speaking back home in their electorates, are on the record as saying that they think there should be greater restrictions on foreign investment. They do not support Senator Messner's view that they should oppose this legislation on the foreign purchase of real estate.

I suppose that the Opposition's official stance these days should be the document called Future Directions which was released with great fanfare just before Christmas last year by the Leader of the Opposition. What does Future Directions have to say about this issue? Future Directions says the following:
In recent years these restrictions have encouraged a dramatic increase in the proportion of debt in total capital inflows and in turn this has an adverse impact on our balance of payments.
These controls-
that is, the foreign investment controls-

should be abolished, except for certain strategic areas such as the media, and with them the Foreign Investment Review Board. They are out of step with the outward looking entrepreneurial spirit we wish to see in Australia.
So there we have the Opposition's official policy on our Government's legislation to try to hold back the amount of foreign investment in Australian residential real estate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inconsistent.

—I thank the honourable member for Perth for his assistance in this; it is certainly inconsistent; according to the Opposition, it is out of step with the Opposition's outward looking entrepreneurial spirit. I am sure that, if members of the Opposition cared to take a sounding in my electorate and in most electorates in Australia, they would find that most Australians are not that concerned about outward looking entrepreneurial spirit. They are concerned about who is purchasing their real estate and who is making it more difficult for them to purchase their homes.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to read the statements by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), the shadow Treasurer and Opposition spokesman in this area. On the Sunday program a few weeks ago he was questioned by Laurie Oakes. The interview was as follows:
Laurie Oakes: Would a Coalition government be more or less regulatory where foreign investment is concerned?

Andrew Peacock: We would be less regulatory. I have no hesitation in saying that and you either believe in a more deregulated society in a greater flow of funds around the world or you don't. Now the Government says one thing and does another and you have seen the sorts of restrictions they impose and they also use the FIRB as a device for other methods.
Laurie Oakes: You say you would be less regulatory but a lot of Coalition members don't want you to be, isn't that true?
Andrew Peacock: Well I don't know that a lot of them do. There are some that I know who are great friends of mine. I would take a different view to them.

There we have it. Even the shadow Treasurer is saying that there is certainly an element in the Opposition which disagrees with his argument that there should be fewer regulatory controls on foreign investment. I am glad to see that some Opposition members support the Government's stance on this issue. I hope that they are able to take a principled position on this when it comes to a vote in this chamber later in the session. I was also interested to read that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition's response to this question was that we should have fewer controls on foreign investment in Australia and should argue for a quid pro quo from other countries, demanding that there should be less hindrance on Australian companies wishing to invest in their countries.

The example that came to my mind was the recent attempts by Elders-IXL to purchase Scottish and Newcastle Brewery in the United Kingdom. The Thatcher Government, on the advice of its foreign investment review body, decided that it was not in the United Kingdom's national interest to have Mr Elliott controlling another brewery in that country. So I suppose what Mr Peacock is saying to us is that he is happy to let more Japanese and British citizens buy land in Australia on condition that Mr Elliott can buy breweries in the United Kingdom. That is not a position that I am prepared to support. I know that my constituents are not prepared to support such an argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —They only like Mrs Thatcher when it suits them.

—As the honourable member for Perth says, Opposition members like to quote Mrs Thatcher on some things but not when she makes laudatory remarks about this Government's achievements in terms of its economic policy. I would not support, and nor would other Government members support, certain measures taken by the Thatcher Government, such as privatisation. I know that Mrs Thatcher's actions in restricting foreign investment in her country may not be the sorts of policies which the Opposition would endorse.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to a particular case which affects my electorate and also the electorate of the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table. It affects the Morisset RSL Country Club, which is in his electorate of Charlton. I know that the Minister has a great deal of interest in the debate that is occurring in our community and I am sure that he will not mind my saying something about the issue, given that the club is very close to the boundary between our electorates. Earlier this year a constituent of mine was contacted by a reporter called Leigh Hatcher, who was then the Channel 7 correspondent in Japan. Mr Hatcher asked my constituent, `Did you know that your local golf course has been advertised for sale in a magazine in Japan?'. That was the first that my constituent, a member of the golf club, knew that his golf club was being put up for sale.

It is a sorry story, but that Returned Services League (RSL) country club went into liquidation in June 1985. The State Bank, which was the mortgagee, appointed receivers to administer the club and make sure that it tried to get out of its difficult financial position. Late last year the guarantor of that loan, the New South Wales branch of the Returned Services League, decided to sell the land and buildings of the Morisset RSL Golf Club. Unfortunately, it appears that it did not put that to tender. As far as I can tell, only one person had an opportunity to put in a bid for the land. That company, Barwar Holdings, made an offer of $3.5m. Yet if one talks to anyone who has considered the value of the Morisset country golf club and the fact that it already has a development approved for its land, one would say that it is worth easily more than $10m. So the question arises: Why did the New South Wales branch of the RSL not put it up for competitive tender so it could get the highest price possible, therefore ensuring that it paid off its debts and maximised the surplus left over?
One other complication which I bring to the House's attention is that during the Whitlam years the regional employment development (RED) scheme grant--

TALK.START.PARA: —Boy, was it a good one!

—The shadow Minister says, by way of interjection, `Wasn't it a good one?'. In those days we had high rates of unemployment. Therefore, the Whitlam Government sought to fund community projects which would result in local people getting employment and improvements in local facilities. Here is an example where the community achieved an improvement: the last nine holes of the golf course were completed which meant that the community went from having a nine-hole golf course to an excellent 18-hole golf course. Now that the golf club has been sold for only $3.5m to Barwar Holdings, one must ask: What has happened to the investment by the people of Australia, through the Commonwealth Government and the RED scheme grant, in those community facilities? I am concerned that the local community of Morisset has not received anything in return from Barwar Holdings or the people who might buy the assets subsequently. Other questions arise, such as how long will the residents of the Morisset area be able to continue to use the facilities at the Morisset golf course? Will they be priced off the course by massive increases in green fees at some later date? What guarantees can be given to the local community that it will be able to continue to use those excellent facilities?

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the House's attention to a glossy brochure which has been produced by Raine and Horne and Baillieu Knight Frank which have put up, on behalf of Barwar Holdings, the assets of that golf club-this time for international tender. The brochure contains a beautiful colour photograph of the area and, with several exceptions, the information it contains is quite extensive. The town of Morisset is not mentioned in all the pages of the brochure. I do not know whether it is thought that the town of Morisset has some bad connotations. I know that the Minister at the table and I do not feel that that is the case. By calling the proposal the Newport country club resort at Lake Macquarie, one would almost think that it is on the North Shore of Sydney rather than at Morisset. I am sure that there were reasons for renaming the golf club the Newport country golf club.

Another minor omission is that in this glossy brochure one can see beautiful Lake Macquarie and the golf course but there are no photographs of the chimney stacks at the local power stations. As I used to work at the Eraring power station I am reasonably certain that I have my bearings correct. But, having looked at the brochure carefully I can find no chimney stacks. I suspect that the photograph has been doctored. I think that someone has painted out the Eraring power station, which is not easy to do, given that it is one of the largest power stations in the Southern Hemisphere. The Vales Point and Munmorah power stations may be just out of the range of the photograph or else they have been touched up as well.

Those who used to work in the local power industry believe that it is not inconsistent to have a power station and a golf course in the same area. Often, many of us who used to work at the Eraring power station used to play at Morisset golf course on a Tuesday afternoon after work. I cannot see any reason why people should be embarrassed to say that there is a power station nearby. Perhaps, when one is seeking to get the best price when one goes out to international tender for a golf course, one does not like to highlight the fact that there is a power station nearby.

Another matter which I bring to the House's attention concerns Anzac Day which falls later this month. It has been a bit of a tradition at the RSL clubs in my electorate that games of two-up, which are technically illegal, have been-I have learnt this through rumours-known to be held at several of my local RSL clubs. The profits that are made are always passed on to local veterans' charities, such as Brisbane Water Legacy. Large amounts of money have been made available. I was sad to learn from my State member of Parliament, Harry Moore, that the New South Wales Police have warned local RSL clubs that they risk losing their licences if they allow any two-up games on their premises on Anzac Day. I cannot endorse anyone breaking the law, but one would expect the New South Wales Police to use a bit of commonsense on Anzac Day, the day when traditionally in Australia returned servicemen get together. I hope that the New South Wales Police will reconsider their decision on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is approximately six years since, in our old parliamentary chamber, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), on coming to government with the Treasurer (Mr Keating), called together the unions, leaders of industry and various groups within Australia to try to determine the future economic direction of this country. Six years further down the track, it is rather interesting to look back on those discussions and to see what they have meant for Australia. Each and every one of us must at times sit down and wonder why this lucky country has not progressed further than it has. Maybe we are to blame. Maybe prior to 1983 and the coming of the Government that is now on the treasury bench, we had not accomplished and set the tide for some of the directions that we should follow. Looking further back to the Whitlam days from 1972 to 1975, that surely was a period in the history of Australia when we took the wrong direction in many ways.

SPEECH.PARA: Those six years having gone by, let us look at where Australia stands in terms of our standard of living and in comparison with other countries with which we trade. Australia has had a wonderful opportunity and it has squandered that opportunity over the years. I wonder whether we are living up to the expectations of our pioneers when they came here and cleared the country, started industry, built roads and established shipping and all the transport that we have today. One must ask why, with the wonderful natural resources we have in Australia, we turn around and ship them overseas, in most cases for processing? We are buying back some of the products that originated here and should be processed here.

Australia is a lucky country in respect of its conditions of work. When we compare our average weekly hours, and our pay and conditions with those of our countries, we surely must ask ourselves: Do we deserve to live in this country? We will certainly get the answer as to why productivity has not increased. As the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), said today during the matter of public importance debate, productivity has barely increased; it has not increased one per cent. We have not been able to take advantage of all the technology that we have been lucky to gain from other more learned parts of the world. We have reached the situation where it does not pay to transport our natural resources from one centre to another; it pays to transport them overseas for processing. We must ask ourselves on many occasions: Why is Australia in such a position? We certainly are a lucky country, but is this luck starting to run out? The Government that is on the treasury bench today is particularly fortunate because in its six years of administration we have seen a series of good world commodity prices. Furthermore, we have had excellent seasons throughout Australia. We have been readily able to obtain markets throughout the world for our primary industries and for the natural resources that I spoke of earlier. Those markets have been there.

We have been lucky to have overseas investment in Australia. People should not say that we do not need Japanese investment. I support the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), although we would like to see the Japanese investing in manufacturing and not in real estate. But this Government welcomes the Japanese investment in Australia because it is money that is keeping us going. Over the years the Americans, the British and the Germans have invested large amounts of money to help us to develop this country. Sure, reins must be held, and we have continually to study the position to see that no country is taking advantage of a land which belongs to our people. I am sure that a responsible government will do that and the Government, undoubtedly, is looking at that problem at this time. We welcome investment, whether it be by the Japanese, the Asians, the British, the Germans or the Americans, while it can be of advantage to us and can employ people in Australia.

One can go on and talk about some of the problems that we have to tackle. I do not want to spend all of the short time I have available criticising the Government. However, I say this to it: The direction it took after the conference in 1973 in the old House of which I spoke earlier is not paying off at this time. Sure, there was a benefit. The accord withheld wage increases for a certain period and probably still has a great effect in that regard, but embedded within that agreement is no flexibility and no deregulation of our rigid system of wages and conditions.

We have invested quite a lot of money in China to assist the Chinese. If we go to China or Russia, or any of the socialist countries of the world, we will find that people are paid for productivity. They are paid for the work that they do and the hours that they work but, more importantly, for the quality and the quantity of the product that they turn off their machines. This is the point Australia has to come to. We have reached the stage where the accord has failed. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister know that it has failed. On Wednesday night this week they will try to come up with a solution that will be politically beneficial so far as the next election is concerned in a desperate attempt to get this economy back on track again. Behind them are all the mistakes that they, and maybe we, have made over past years.

We have let this country go down the drain and we have not pulled it up. This country has failed to work. That is an important fact. We have failed to produce the policies that will give incentive to our people to work and produce. Productivity is the basic issue behind the future of this country. The Japanese have proved that, as have the Americans and other Western countries. These countries have proved, as we have in years gone by, that government can set policies for work but it will never achieve this with a rigid wages policy and rigid working conditions. We all want to see decent conditions of work. While we have that rigidity we have not the flexibility or the incentive to put this country back onto its proper course.

The backdrop to our economy has been spoken of in this chamber. Let us compare the backdrop of a bad and mounting balance of trade and a growing national debt with our own households. If we spend more than is coming in, where will we finish up? Furthermore, let us look at our consumer price index. In the August Budget the Treasurer said that it would be down to 4.5 per cent at the end of this financial year. It is not; it is nearly twice that figure. This proves again that on economic policy the Government is on the wrong track.

Let us look at interest rates today. I do not disagree with the tightening of our monetary or fiscal policy at the moment. It has been brought about by necessity. It has been brought about to stop people spending. But that does not get away from the fact that house purchasers are paying tremendous interest. On my way to Canberra last night a young man from Sydney told me that he was going to borrow $150,000 to buy a semi-detached house. I said to him, `My lad, that is going to cost you $500 or more a week in interest'. He said, `I know. But how else can I afford to buy what I want?'. Fortunately he was on a reasonable salary and was a single man. But there are many who are not in this situation. The backdrop of which I have spoken is there and is not healthy for this country.

The Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table, is genuine in his attempts to supply money for roads. I am sure that he would do all he could to get money from the Treasurer and the Cabinet to satisfy the demands for roads in Australia. The fact of the matter is that we should look at where our money is being spent. I spoke a while ago about the poor productivity of Australia. If we go into our communities we will see where a lot of the taxpayers' money is being spent. It is being spent on crisis cottages and refuge places. Through clubs such as Rotary, Lions, Apex and Quota the community is drawing itself together to try to finance these particular projects. Today 5,000,000 Australians are dependent upon social security. Somebody has to supply the money. The average man who works for a council and for the industries of this country must be able not only to purchase his own home and pay the interest rate but also to pay the taxes required to keep this nation going.

We should look at our Family Courts. We should look at the other problems that we have in an endeavour not only to solve the economic problems that we are talking about but also to get Australian families back on the track again. Australian families as well as our economy have gone down the drain. If we look at the statistics today we will see how many de facto relationships we have in this country. We can compare that with the downward trend in the economy. There is a great relationship. De facto relationships may be the fashion like the way we wear our hair and clothes. Maybe as time progresses things will change. Maybe we will say that it is time that we woke up to ourselves and looked at our economy in a sensible way, put ourselves back to work, got our families back together again and raised our standard of living.

I am saying to this House that we have gone down hill. Who will bring us back again? This is the important issue. We should not worry about foreign purchases of golf courses and all the other things that I hear people speak of in this House. These things are infinitesimal in comparison. What matters is getting Australia back into an atmosphere which is conducive to world trade. Surely to goodness we have the potential with our natural resources and entrepreneurial skills to achieve this. We have people, both big and small, who have proved it. They have been able to succeed in the way they would like. Many of our investors have placed their money off-shore. I do not blame them for that. On balance, that may be the thing to do. But it concerns me that the little Australian who wants to start a manufacturing business around the corner or whatever it may be is unable to employ the people necessary to help develop this country of ours. We are not in a position at the present time to do that.

We have to ask ourselves a lot of questions, particularly during a debate such as the one before the House. We must ask ourselves: Where are we going wrong? I hope that the Treasurer in his statement on Wednesday night of this week will talk not only of taxation concessions but also of some of those positive things that really matter so far as Australia is concerned. I hope something will be said about privatisation. This country has grown up. The little entrepreneurs of whom I speak want to invest in their country. They want to have confidence in putting their money into Australia in the same way as the British have in Britain. Every member of this House should ask himself: Why is it that Britain is back on the rails again? If one were to go to Britain one would find out. Not only does Britain have a better standard of living but also that country is developing itself. In the East End, 8,500 acres have been cleared up. We talk about Darling Harbour in Sydney and the little bit that we do. That old part of London has been completely refurbished. Why is it that Britain can come back? We can take a lesson from some of the things that Margaret Thatcher and her Government have done in England. First of all, her Government has put confidence back into the people. Nobody is putting confidence into the average Australian.

I went round my electorate at the weekend and I found no confidence in the people I spoke to. Unfortunately, people are misdirected in many respects today. They say, `The Government is not capable of doing the job. What are you people going to do? What are your policies?'. The gallup polls today show that many people are looking beyond the three major political parties. It is time that we all pulled up our socks and realised that people want to think positively and come up with a policy that will get this country back to work. They want us to come up with a policy that will put confidence back into the hearts of our people. That is an important issue. There is nothing wrong with the younger generation of today. It is a matter of giving it the education and confidence to actually do the job.

I did not want to speak about the issues raised by many honourable members. I wanted to speak of generalities. These are the issues that we must look at. We must look at our principles, our family life, and future initiatives. Somebody criticised that a while ago. I will not criticise it because it is getting back to basics and it is back to basics that we must go. If we continue to get away from the basics that the older generation was taught when it was young, what hope is there for the younger people of Australia today? Let us give them a bit of spirit. Irrespective of the elections that are around the corner, the Government will get more credit from the Australian voter if it does the proper thing than it will get if it does the improper thing, which could well be vote-catching initiatives that are not in the interests of this country. We had better realise it and place ourselves in a situation in which we can all actually contribute more so far as Australia is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I hope that, true to his word, the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) will ensure when the next election comes about that the Opposition will not concentrate on vote-catching initiatives. I must say that I cannot help admiring the honesty with which he made his contribution today and the sincerity with which it was delivered. I suppose it might be a reflection of the age difference between us, but I cannot necessarily agree that the number of de facto relationships in our society now is in direct relationship to our economic malaise. I grew up in a different era, in a time when a popular lyricist, Bob Dylan, made the hit parades with a song called The Times They Are A-changin'. The words were taken from a biblical context, so they were not contemporary; they are a bit older. I seem to remember the song's words going something like this:

SPEECH.PARA: The first one now will later be last
The order is rapidly fading
The slow one now will later be fast
For the times they are a-changin'

The times are changing in respect of the way in which relationships develop in society. I do not necessarily see that as a bad thing. I see it as people choosing to live their lives differently. So I dissociate myself from the suggestion made by the honourable member opposite. As I have said, I admire the sincerity with which he made his contribution. We could all heed many of the things he said.

Clearly, this Government has made mistakes. Previous governments have made mistakes. What I admire about the present Government is the fact that we have a real approach, a reasoned approach and a philosophical background to our approach. That is important in regard to the way in which government policy is framed. If one looks at the way the Opposition has been operating in the last six years one does not find a philosophical background to, or any sort of direction in, the way it has operated.

When considering these Appropriation Bills, the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1988-89, and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1988-89-when we talk about appropriations we are talking about government expenditure-we have to consider fiscal policy. Time after time the question is asked in this place, and by the media, `What is the Opposition's position on fiscal policy?'. Opposition members make hairy-chested remarks-`We will do this, we will cut expenditure'-but, when it comes down to it, we do not find any substance. Last week the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), came into this place and talked for the first time in a long time about micro-economic reform. But if one looks at the Opposition's record on deregulation and on tariffs one finds no prescription for reform. The Opposition's latest position on fiscal policy is: `We are hoping to sell off lots of government enterprises and that way we will be able to fund our promises when the next election comes around. But we will not have to make any cuts. There will not have to be any cuts. There will not be any hard decisions. We will not tell you that we are going to cut expenditure in education, health, social security or wherever else'.

What is the Opposition's wages policy? We hear words such as `productivity' and `flexibility' thrown around. The position put by the honourable member for Lyne on productivity is one that I would embrace. Productivity has to be an important component of wages policy. But we do not have any evidence that when the Opposition was in government it dealt with the wages problem in a practical way. In 1981 there was a disastrous wage explosion. It led to economic chaos and massive unemployment. It was up to this Government to solve many of those problems.

We hear Opposition members talk about monetary policy, and what a terrible thing it is to have high interest rates. They acknowledge that high interest rates are necessary now as a way of moderating demand. Still, the present interest rates do not compare with the interest rates which the Opposition left us. Still, no alternative prescription for interest rates comes from the Opposition. Day after day we wait to hear something from the Opposition but we hear nothing.

The history of coalition governments-we see it in my own State of Western Australia-is that they are not able to make up their minds. Very often when the national interest is at stake it is the National Party, the agrarian socialists whom we have come to know and love ever since the days of Jack McEwen, which in the end wins on protection or control and it is the Liberal Party which is shown to be important in that equation.

I would like to believe that Opposition members are going to do some of the things that they say they are going to do. Perhaps many people in the community would like to know what they are going to do. They would like to believe that if Opposition members did get into government they actually would do the things they say they would do. Today's West Australian states:
Major enterprises targeted for the sell-off are the two airlines, the Commonwealth Bank, Aussat, Medicare Private and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission.
Telecom and Australia Post would be sold in the first term of a coalition government . . .

The Opposition spokesman on business and consumer affairs, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), Leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland, was asked whether the Nationals would have opposed the inclusion of Australia Post and Telecom. He said, `Oh, well. I don't know about that'. That is the sort of response we are used to hearing coming out of Queensland-`Oh, well. We don't know about that. We will solve that one later'.

Can Opposition members be believed? If we look at the history of the previous coalition Government and at the performance of the coalition in opposition, we find a trail of compromises, or decisions which were not made, as a result of a conflict between the two parties. The Fraser Government, which had control of this place and the upper House, had a record of impotence. Let us consider the statements of the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party in 1985, the present shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown). In respect of the Fraser Government, he said:

But we never seemed to have time to talk about where Australia was going; about the failing standard of living of the ordinary Australians; about how we could give them a good and secure future; about how we could encourage new industries in Australia; and how we could get rid of the dead hand of Government, our Government, that was stifling initiative and taxing us into oblivion.

That is not a criticism from outside; it is an internal criticism of the way the Fraser Government operated. Honourable members may say, `That is a long time ago. How is it relevant now?'. I am suggesting that there has not been a change. We are sitting here waiting-we have been waiting for six years-to hear about the change, the new broom, but there is no evidence of it.

So let us consider the way things are now. If these people really believe in the market, then let us have it from them. Last year we had the gold tax issue. If one is an economic rationalist and one really believes that there should be equal treatment of all industries, that it is inequitable to tax the profits of one industry and leave the profits of another industry to go free, one has to support the gold tax. What does a former Liberal member, John Hyde-certainly not a fellow traveller of those on this side of the House, but a man whom I admire for the tenacity with which he pursues his beliefs and the consistency he shows-say about the Opposition's approach to the gold tax? He says:
If the Federal Liberals really believed in what they did-
he is talking about their opposing the tax-

there would be much less reason to worry about them. It seems, however, that they opposed the gold tax to gain advantage in the coming Western Australian election, and to spite a leader they will not support but cannot replace.
Such pettiness and spite merely demonstrate their unfitness to govern.

So we have criticism of the way the Fraser Government operated, criticism of the fact that it did not have a philosophical or reasoned approach to the way it did things. We find that, in opposition, honourable members opposite continue this trend. We would have hoped that the Opposition would have sorted it out, but it does not seem that that change has occurred.

I have given an example of the shadow Attorney-General's view of how the Fraser Government operated. We have seen a more recent test of how the Opposition operates: the gold tax. More recently it has been said of the wheat issue, `Wheat: the test of Coalition competence'. Again I quote John Hyde, clearly a supporter of the Liberal Party. He commented in the Australian of last weekend:

Labor's micro-economic reform program includes abolition of the Wheat Board monopoly of the domestic market. It is a measure of the Coalition's difficulties that it looked like dividing on this straightforward issue. If the Liberals cannot get their Coalition partner to support even as much micro-economic reform as Labor is implementing, then the Coalition is not ready to govern.

Once again we get from a sympathiser with the Opposition the concept that the Opposition is not able to face up to the problems, the concept of the Opposition being divided with, once again, the dead hand of the National Party winning when it comes to micro-economic change and deregulation. One would think that the coalition could easily come to the conclusion that the deregulation of wheat marketing was in the best interests of all Australians, but unfortunately that is not the case.

Let us look at the Opposition's latest proposal to sell Qantas Airways Ltd. That is a view for which many on this side of the House have some sympathy. The honourable member for Ryan suggested on the weekend that the two airlines be merged before Qantas was sold. The suggestion that there should be deregulation of air travel and civil aviation clearly is supported by this side of the House because the Government moved to remove the two airlines agreement which was for so long a straitjacket on civil aviation in this country. It took the Fraser Government six years to face up to the issue. In May 1981 it finally discussed it and decided, after holding an inquiry, that the two airlines agreement would continue for five more years and that there would be a three-year notice of termination. Effectively, the Fraser Government said it was not sure that it should continue with the policy, but that it would try it out for another eight years.

The former member for Stirling-I note that the present member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) is in the chair-and the honourable member for Forrest cried crocodile tears about the fact that there should be deregulation of air travel. Fortunately for the coalition, those two members were out of the House when the vote was taken and were paired with members of the then Opposition. So in May 1981, the two airlines agreement legislation was passed, even though many members from Western Australia crossed the House in a show of support for the then Opposition, which was support for Labor's approach. Unfortunately, while crying crocodile tears about the fact that the legislation had been passed, two of the members from Western Australia could not make it to the House to vote. Had they been there, the then Government's legislation would have failed. So I ask whether we can believe what the Opposition is saying. Opposition members have been tested on a number of occasions. They have been asked whether they are serious about the market and about deregulation. They have been asked whether they are serious about their motivation and whether, if they get to government, they can deliver. Time and time again they have failed the test. They have failed even the most recent test in the last weeks. It is right and proper that the people of Australia should ask themselves whether they can trust this mob opposite. If they were successful, could we believe them?

We find the same difficulty if we consider the Opposition's wages policy. The Opposition has no concepts. We must ask what is its prescription. A few buzz words like `flexibility' are thrown around, but there is no substance to the policy of those opposite. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong, in a most remarkable contribution on the matter of public importance, said, `How you decide what a person should get is easy. A man ought to get what he ought to get'. I presume that means that if someone on the shop floor is not sure what he is worth, he goes to the boss and says, `We'd like 20 per cent, but we're a bit concerned about the condition of Australia-inflation, the current account deficit and productivity-and we understand that productivity is only trending at 1 1/2 per cent, so we will accept 1 1/2 per cent. Inflation might be running at 6 per cent, but in the interests of Australia we'll accept 1 1/2 per cent' and, whizz bang, we will have the sort of wages policy that the Opposition proposes and it will work. But we know that is not what will happen because at the moment we have significant employment and a large number of job opportunities. We have a market which, because of its profit share, can afford to pay 12 per cent or 15 per cent. If collective bargaining is allowed and workers negotiate their own deals, we will have 1982 revisited. We have seen the possibility of wage break-out with the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Qantas Airways Ltd and other areas. Under the scorched earth philosophy of the Opposition, we would have a huge wage break-out and no way to take the step from the process we have at the moment to productivity.

No-one on this side of the House suggests that productivity should not be a factor; of course, it should. But it is necessary and important for us to understand that there needs to be some mechanism by which members opposite put in place the wages policy that they propose. We have not seen it; we are still waiting to see it. We hear a few buzz words. We see a policy that is working, that is historically breaking the nexus between the consumer price index and wages growth in this country. We see a philosphy behind it and we see something that works, yet we are supposed to jump into the darkness in the hope that perhaps if we use a couple of these buzz words, there will be a solution. Indeed, it is right and proper that the people of Australia should look at what the Opposition proposes and question it very closely. If the proposal cannot pass their scrutiny, the Opposition will fail.

There is no suggestion by this side of the House that an employment and wages policy is easy. It is damned hard and has been difficult, but we have a conceptual approach. We have a philosophical background to the way in which we are going; that is something that the Opposition does not have. As long as we are the only party which has that sort of direction and purpose, and as long as the Opposition remains divided and inconsistent and unable to put forward a concrete proposal, I imagine that all Australians will continue to support us rather than the Opposition. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to speak generally on our economic situation in the context of these Appropriation Bills. They are very relevant because they are an important part in the Government's armoury in dealing with the problems that the nation faces at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Appropriation Bills deal with the additional funding that is required for the maintenance of the provision of services by government. They enable the Government, if it has a determination to do something about the fiscal side of our economy, also to redress in part some of the expenditure patterns adopted by the Government. In other words, there is in the appropriation legislation an opportunity to cut back, as it were, on some areas of government expenditure.

Essentially, as I understand it, we have before us a document that is largely neutral, which indicates very little resolve on the part of the Government to deal with the dilemma that the nation faces at this time. We may see a little more light shed on these matters when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) speaks to the Parliament on Wednesday, but I suspect, in terms of what I read and hear, that the statement that we will hear will have more to do with the Government's short term survival than with realistically addressing the longer term problems that the nation faces.

If what I hear and read is correct, I am likely as an Australian to be disappointed. If, however, the Government is taking a longer term view-the approach that the Government appeared to be taking before the last election; in other words, that it would make the hard and the necessary decisions for Australia and its future and it wanted to separate out its future in a sense and say, `Look, we don't really care if we survive; if we do what's right for Australia we will be satisfied'-so much the better.

In the context of a debate which is not being broadcast but which will be read by those who look at Hansard, I will try to put on the record some of the matters that are of concern to me as a parliamentarian about the position we are in at this time. I refer honourable members to the `Overview' section of the Economic Round-up, the Treasury document about the Government's performance. We need only look at the short paragraphs, the cryptic phrases which describe quite clearly our position. Under the heading `Balance of Payments', in the page 1 overview, we see that the current account deficit in the month of January was about $1,537m. That was compared with the December period in which it was $924m. In the first seven months of 1988-89, the current account deficit was $9,643m. That was $2,553m higher than the deficit recorded in the same period of 1987-88. Then the document goes on to explain, as much as is possible, that the high level of imports seen in recent months continued during the three months to January 1989. The total value of endogenous imports was 19 per cent higher than in the same period of 1987-88. The total value of exports increased by 2.3 per cent in the same period.

What worries me is that when we look at the outcome of the balance of payments we find that each month we are falling further and further behind. As I often say to people in my electorate as I talk about these questions-and I do discuss these questions with them-when one falls behind in one's own accounting and individual expenditure pattern and spends more than one earns month after month one knows the likely outcome. Most people understand that if one continues to spend more than one earns there are not many options left. One's first option is to cut back on what one buys-in other words, on consumption. The country can do that. It can cut back on consumption and imports. The Government has a say about some of these things. The way it frames its policies will determine whether people are encouraged to consume. That is what the individual and the nation can do to deal with the situation.

But the individual has other approaches available, such as borrowing money. As long as a person has reasonable credit and some assets, he or she might be able to go out and pledge those. I do not know how frequently you, Mr Deputy Speaker, go out and pledge your credit or borrow in order to live, to meet school fees, to run a few extra parties at home or whatever; but I imagine that if you were borrowing for consumption you, like me, would feel that that was not a very satisfying way in which to live. In fact, this is what our nation is doing. Part of the way in which we are attempting to balance our economy is by borrowing money. Some people ask: why are we borrowing money from Japan? Why are we going into hock? It does not matter where the money is coming from. The fact is that we are going into hock. It does not matter whether one chooses to borrow money from Westpac or from the ANZ Bank. If it is needed, one goes out and borrows it. The nation borrows it internationally. The problem is that, generally speaking, what we are doing as a nation is going into hock for consumption.

There is one other option left. As I frequently explain to people, one can sell some assets. I do not know how much of one's assets one could sell. Perhaps one could subdivide the garage and sell it to a neighbour. Perhaps one could get rid of some of the furniture. A person who has been living well in the past and has a lot of antiques might be able to sell some of those. In fact, that is what the nation has been doing. It has been selling off the farm, selling off our future. I hear complaints around the electorate. People say, `Is it not dreadful? We have people from Asia investing in Australia'. It does not matter whether those investments come from Asia, the United States of America or Britain: the fact is that a person who sells off his garage for consumption purposes is doing exactly the same as Australia is doing now.

The deficit that we see each month is being accommodated essentially in two ways at this time: by borrowing from overseas and by bringing overseas capital into Australia. The amounts involved are large. Quite frankly, while we can cut back on our imports as a more satisfactory way of dealing with this matter, if we look at what we export and what we import in terms of our merchandise trade we find that Australia is buying largely the same amount of tradable goods from overseas as it is able to sell in the various categories in which we export-mineral products, agricultural products and the like. That merchandise trade in 1987-88 totalled $40.5 billion and the imports totalled $40,386m, which is roughly comparable. Australia was dropping behind in what we call the invisibles-those items for which we pay other people to carry out certain services. It may be in terms of shipping, insurance or any of those sorts of matters, but the principal payments are in fact to service the debt. They are interest payments on debt. As a nation with a gross foreign indebtedness last December of $120,834m, we have a huge interest bill to meet each year. The fact of the matter is that each year as we continue to go into debt we are compounding our interest obligations.

These statistics are not pleasant reading. They are signs of the enormous problem that we face as a nation. The statistics that we as members of parliament are provided with by the Parliamentary Library-and I use the merchandise trade figures again-show that over time our position has improved in terms of the export of primary products, mainly agricultural products. The improvement has not been significant in percentage terms but largely in the value of the products sold. We have seen an increase in our exports of primary products from $8 billion worth in 1982 to about $15 billion worth in 1987-88. These consisted of wheat, wool and the like. Of course, that is as a result of the marginal recovery that we have seen in relation to our rural industries.

I was interested to read an article in Time magazine of 3 April entitled `Rural riches', which talks about the bush economy booming and new industries being created. I thought it was rather good reading for Australia. But, notwithstanding all the improvement in relation to our primary products, the overall situation of merchandise trade has not changed significantly. Our capacity to reduce our foreign debt as a result of the rural riches has been marginal, if any. As a person who contemplates these things, I do not like to think ill of Australia or its future. But if we see a significant downturn in the rural economy in the near future or perhaps in a year or two, the fact is that we will not have used those opportunities resulting from the rural boom to reduce our foreign indebtedness.

If the country suffers a major drought in the near future, the nation's position will be worse than it was when we suffered a drought in the time of the Fraser Government. Instead of being in a position to weather the storm, we will be much worse off as a consequence. I do not believe that these problems are being seriously addressed by the Treasurer at this time. I do not think his statement on Wednesday night will take the problems into account. If one is going to address these problems, one has to reduce the nation's imports of overseas products. One assumes that the nation's exports are largely maximised, but I will come to that in a moment. If the Treasurer proposes to reduce taxation at this time and intends not to impose a consumer tax, which does not seem to be on the horizon and if wages are to be increased-and the Government is about to agree to a number of arrangements for that, which seems to be the way in which those who are informed about these matters are suggesting that the Government is going to go-the reality is consumption will increase and imports will increase. The Government will be further jeopardising the nation's capacity to reduce its indebtedness. That is the hard reality, but it is what we are likely to see.

I must say that I think there are some other matters that need to be commented on and I shall do it briefly. I noticed that many of my colleagues speaking in this debate addressed some of the micro-economic problems that the nation faces rather than the macro questions on which I have tried to comment. The micro-economic reforms that it is believed are appropriate for Australia are those that will enable the nation to become more efficient, more productive and to increase its exports. That is the other side of the equation. Those micro-economic reforms have been suggested to me by economists whenever I have spoken to them, either here or abroad. They are essentially about adding value to products which we in Australia produce. Nobody suggests that there is any miraculous new industry that we can create overnight. If one is going to look at Australia's strengths, one has to identify the areas in which we do it well and find out how we can do it better-how we can add value to those rural or mined products that we export-how we can add that value ourselves and get a better price for those products.

The areas are quite clear. Honourable members talk about them frequently. Uranium is one. Wood pulp is another. As the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), who spoke before me in the debate, suggested, wheat products are another. I want to talk about each of those. In the area of uranium we have a Government that has its head in the sand and is not prepared to bite the bullet on that question. We could not only export more uranium; we could carry out processes here which would make it more valuable as an exported product for Australia. On the wood pulp question, Wesley Vale was an important project for Australia not only because of the expenditure it would have involved but also because of the value added wood pulp that would have been exported from Australia. This Government was not prepared to enter into negotiations with the Tasmanian Government about what would be appropriate environmental safeguards until the Tasmanian Government hung out its shingle and said, `We are prepared to buy this project'. Then the Federal Government came in and said, `We are not prepared to be involved in that. We do not think you have gone in hard enough'. This Government wanted to establish its environmental credentials, but it sabotaged an important development project which would have had significant micro-economic benefits for this country.

On the subject of wheat, the honourable member for Perth suggested that the Opposition parties lack credentials in that area. The coalition is in favour of deregulation but what we say to the Government is, `Be serious. This is an area where effective micro-economic reform can occur, but it cannot just occur in relation to the matter of the Wheat Board. It has to include the other elements that are important-freight and the question of getting the product through this country's very complex and difficult wharfing systems'.

Those are matters that the Government needs to address, as well as the way in which wheat is sold domestically, if the system is to see realistic reform. These sorts of micro-economic reforms are important for Australia, but I very much doubt that in the statement we are going to see later this week the Government will have seriously addressed them. I doubt that the Government will show that it has any idea about the way this country can increase the value of its exports or effectively reduce imports. If the statement does not address these problems, this nation's future is seriously at risk. I ask honourable members to look at an article that was published in the Sydney Morning Herald a few weeks ago, written by Maximilian Walsh, a leading economics reporter. The article was headed `The edge of our ruin is now in sight'. I think it is important that all members appreciate the sorts of issues that are canvassed and that article will help them if they wish to be informed.
