SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has demonstrated again how easy it is to govern a country when one is in opposition. It is very simple. I think the honourable member ought to go back to what the Government of which he was a member did, particularly in the period between 1978 and 1981. I ask him to listen not to what I say about that period but to what the Metal Trades Industry Association said about it. It seems that what the honourable member is saying now in opposition does not link up with what actually took place during that period, when firms moved offshore and the former Government was winding down the ability of Australian companies to compete and forcing upon them a moat mentality when it came to exporting. The honourable member spoke about value added now, when this Government has given incentives to Australian industries to produce in this country and to export, having processed their products to the maximum. The honourable member referred also to the country's international debt. I am constantly amazed, for if one looks at the facts and figures one finds that over $60 billion of the money owed by this country was chalked up by private enterprise, not by this Government. The honourable member tends to make out that the reverse is the situation, but the suggestion is totally untrue.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dundas mentioned foreign investment. I agree and have concerns about foreign investment where it involves the vertical integration of control of, say, the beef industry. But the coalition parties want to remove the Foreign Investment Review Board. Their policy is to get rid of it. The Government's approach is that that investment ought to be allowed if it is in the national interest, which is a very good rule.

I want to talk about another aspect that I believe is important in Australia's future interests, just as the economic issues are, and it has economic overtones. I refer to the growing demand that is developing in this country and in the Australian community generally for the nation's heritage to be protected and preserved. When one starts thinking about the nation's heritage one looks at three areas: first, the natural environment, and those involved in the conservation environmental groups have certainly brought that home to every household. The preservation of Aboriginal history has also been put high on the agenda by the Hawke Labor Government so that the sacred sites and artefacts and any aspect to do with the Aboriginal heritage are protected, and money has been made available from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to achieve that.

The third aspect is the historic heritage. I think the bicentennial year and the whole lead-up to it spotlighted and highlighted the average Australian's new and, I would hope, continuing and developing interest in his or her own country. It certainly is so in my area. As I walk around my electorate and meet with people I find that more and more of them are saying, `We want to preserve what we have got. We have a history here; let us protect it'. The activities in 1988 involved millions of individuals, tens of thousands of organisations and over 850 local authorities and all other levels of government. In that year the nation spent $100m on bricks and mortar projects-a substantial amount of taxpayers' money, but money that was well spent. It was not only $100m on the bricks and mortar; one could almost double that for the money that was spent during the bicentennial year, but the activities awakened Australians everywhere to the historic heritage around them. It gave Australians a better understanding of the need to protect and preserve this heritage. It created an interest in projects that were not previously recognised-projects of an historic nature. Regrettably, much of this interest was belated. I have had groups, not only in my electorate but all over Queensland, say to me, `We did not realise until it was too late that there was a closing date for applications. We missed out on getting funding for these projects'. The moneys had been spent or allocated before they realised that their project was worth while.

But regardless of the belatedness of that interest, I am pleased that there is now a very positive and significant post-bicentennial mentality. There is also an emphasis on the historic. I see that it is starting to compete with the interest in our natural heritage that has been engendered by the greenies, those involved in the conservation movement. Right across this country hundreds of projects are now being brought forward as projects worthy of support. All sorts of local museums are springing up. The preservation of homes of famous people is being placed high on the agenda of local communities. Sites of historic events are also being seen as something worth researching, developing and then presenting to the world. The link between tourism and cultural and historical projects is quite exciting as well. We then have the programs commemorating events, people and places to the point where some people are saying that we ought to have a plaques campaign right across the nation so that people know where a certain famous person lived or an event took place. There is increasing interest and that interest is being seen by the demand on the National Estate program and in the activities of organisations such as the National Trust.

The Federal Hawke Labor Government has certainly played a magnificent role in creating this interest and in placing a special emphasis on Australiana. It certainly did this during the bicentennial period with the allocation of about $170m. But now I suggest that we need to address this post-bicentennial interest. We need to ensure that money is available for the hundreds of groups across the nation that are starting to say, `Our projects need support'. So there is a need for a more national approach now. Instead of leaving it to the States, to local communities and to local authorities we need a national approach to the preservation and presentation of Australia's historic heritage.

I want quickly to acknowledge the work that has been done by the Australian Heritage Commission, the role that it plays in the identification, listing, registering and researching of sites and events of the past. I think we all appreciate that the work that has been done by the Australian Heritage Commission has been enhanced by the National Trust, a body which is set up by individual State legislation and works mainly on a State basis but which has a national council. Those bodies combine well, through the independence of the National Trust and the Commission, to ensure that Australians are well aware of what we have and what we ought to keep.

Governments have acknowledged the need to preserve history. At the State level, museum grants are given to hundreds of small museums in my State. Funds are also forthcoming for national bodies such as the National Trust. But I would suggest that it is important that we have a more up to date, nationwide Federal assistance program that would enhance what I think is probably the most important program at the moment-the National Estate grants program. The Fraser Government spent about $2m on that program, whereas this year we have spent almost $4m. That money is available for capital works programs. In the past it has been distributed through the States, although this will change and I believe that it will be administered through the Australian Heritage Commission. But it is a scheme where the States have to set the priorities and I think that is a pity. But the advantages have been that that money can be made available to State projects, local government projects and non-government projects and, where an approved body is involved, there can be tax exemptions.

I know also that we have other assistance programs, such as the Commonwealth commemoration programs, that involve the national memorial program, which is Canberra based, and the National Memorials Committee which centres on Parliament House. The only program that is really worth while is the historical events and famous persons program. It sounds great because of the work that has been done with it but this year only $36,000 is available for the whole of the nation. When $20,000 was used in an archaeological research program in Barcaldine for the shearers' camp site it does not leave much if we want to put up a plaque for an historic person's home or to commemorate an historical event. There is a real need to acknowledge the importance of commemorating events and recognising the people who have made the history of this country.

I acknowledge that there are other moneys but I suggest that they are in bits and pieces. Funds are available through the Australian research grants but there are strong restrictions on these grants. The Australian Geographic Society is developing a science program but limited funds are available. The National Museum of Australia is starting to get going but again it does not have access to massive government funds. The Australian biological resources study grants are mainly for the study and research of flora and fauna. As I mentioned before, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has done excellent work in Aboriginal history but that is limited to Aboriginal heritage. The State museum grants are State grants.

I acknowledge also that there are tax incentives for gifts of art works or gifts of property, but again they are limited. Whilst research moneys are available in tourism there are limitations. In fact, there are limitations on all areas despite the bits and pieces that are available. I add also the Australia Council grants for commemorative art.

Throughout the nation there is an urgency to preserve all sorts of projects. One matter that must surely raise the concern of Australians everywhere is the fact that we have never really researched the Eureka Stockade site at Ballarat. Many say that we cannot say exactly where it was but that is why we ought to research it. It ought to be a centre of activity. One could add to that Vinegar Hill in New South Wales, scene of the Irish uprising. It is very interesting history but no-one is quite sure about the location and nothing has really been done about it in substantial terms because the money has not been available. Captain Cook's landing place at Kurnell is another one that could be added. Funding has been raised for the Barcaldine Tree of Knowledge and the Australian Labor Party's interpretative centre. This is important because it is the beginning of the history of the Labor movement. Eventually the Liberal Party of Australia will have its own history to commemorate, as will the National Party of Australia.

We can add the homes of the famous, such as Ben Chifley's home at Bathurst. The locals have tried to do something about it but it ought to be a national project. Dame Enid Lyons's home in Tasmania ought to be a national project. D. H. Lawrence's `Whywuark' home at Thirroul in Wollongong ought to be a national project. Donald Bradman's houses at Moss Vale ought to be national projects. Lloyd Rees's home ought to be a national project.

If we walk away from the famous people we could start talking about our explorers and the pioneer trails. I suggest that there would be great value in setting down the expedition tracks far better than they have been, left to local authorities. In my area Leichhardt went through the township of Moranbah. The locals are trying to raise money to do something about that site. It is important, it is historic but there is no money available and it ought to be part of a national program. I would even suggest that we consider Prime Ministers' homes. In the United States of America, once a person has been a President, his home is set aside and it is part of the American heritage, but not in this country. I believe that the homes of our Prime Ministers from the beginning in 1901 ought to be of national significance. We can add other famous people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Treasurers?

—Short of treasurers, we can add other famous people, such as May Gibbs, the author of the story about the famous gumnut babies, Snugglepot and Cuddlepie. Her home should be added. These things are important to our heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: I come now to my State of Queensland. I remind honourable members of King O'Malley. People in Emu Park are trying to establish a museum to commemorate King O'Malley-a man who went to Emu Park to die and was saved by an Aboriginal person by the name of Coowoonga. He found King O'Malley in a cave and nursed him back to health. We cannot get money for the King O'Malley museum. The Peak Downs homestead will deteriorate to a point where it will never be saved unless we can get money. The Mount Morgan chimney stack, which is rather unique in the goldmining history of this country, is deteriorating to a point where, unless we can get the Army to help us repair it from the top using helicopters or some other significant scaffolding exercise, it will be lost. The Rockhampton Archer Park railway station is the centre of railway history in central Queensland, but the money is simply not available for its preservation. In Biloela we have something more adventurous. People have bought the silo from World Expo 88 and want it to be a centre of grazing, agricultural and mining history. The first coal ever exported from this country came from the Callide-Dawson Valley. Those people need $1m, but it is not available.

The Chinese massacres that took place with the gold exploration of central Queensland may be something that we want to forget, but it is part of our history. It ought to be plaqued in some way-presented, researched and represented. I have mentioned Leichhardt's journey through the central highlands and Moranbah. One could go on and on. Riversleigh, which is some 140 kilometres north of Mount Isa, has the largest, most important fossil bed in this nation. It is of international renown. Yet Professor Mike Archer of the University of New South Wales depends on private enterprise support, private support, some National Estate grants and Australian research grants. That fossil bed has giant rhinoceroses and minute particles of animals and reptiles. All those things should be part of a national plan. I could add to that the need for a national portrait gallery. I note that the old Parliament House is being considered as a possible site for that. There should be a national campaign ofidentification. Regarding plaques, while the Australian Geographic Society has a signs program I believe plaques should be dealt with at a national level.

I argue for these things because they cannot be put off. Unless we start taking action now, the homes will be lost and the sites destroyed. Therefore, the information will disappear. We need to take a bipartisan approach and say that this cannot be left to local authorities, local interest groups and a local museum group that suddenly desires to research a project and build a museum, as we are trying to do at Emu Park with King O'Malley. We need to expand the funds that are available. I suggest that a massive expansion of the National Estate's grants program is needed. We also need to set up a heritage trust-a trust run by the Australian Heritage Commission or similar body that can attract direct funds from State and Federal governments, private sector support and a tax deductability right for the donors. In other words, we need a massive national pool of money. We need between $30m and $40m a year. At the minimum we need $20m to be able to get on with the preservation, restoration, renovation and protection of these sites.

When a project comes forward it can be funded on its merit. If it is of national importance it should receive 100 per cent national funding. If it has a State emphasis, it could be funded on a 50 : 50 basis where the States weigh in a dollar for a dollar. If it is on a local regional basis, it could be funded on a 40 : 40 : 20 basis-that is, 40 per cent from the Commonwealth, 40 per cent from the State and 20 per cent from either the local authority or the community. Obviously, it should be assessed properly before funding is available, but the money must be there. We need to adopt a long term program; not a program running for two or three years or the life of one parliament, but a 10-year program reflecting a commitment by both sides of the House that these nationally important projects will be funded and that we will commit ourselves to that funding either legislatively or by a special political commitment. If we do this I believe that will be backed by the people of this country.

More and more people realise the need to preserve the past for the future. There is a need to take advantage of our history-a tourist advantage-because some 17 planes come to Australia from Japan every week. Visitors are not only interested in visiting beaches on the Gold Coast; they want to know what Australia is all about. They want to know something of the Aboriginal history. They want to go to Ayers Rock and they want to see Australia as it was in the past, as it is presented today. I stress the need for a national Australian approach.

I would urge that as Government and honourable members think through the forthcoming budgetary allocations that we will have this year and in years to come, they need to place the preservation of our country at the top of the agenda. We need to say that unless we do so, these things will be lost. I urge that that national approach be taken, that consultation be held with the States and local authorities and that we embark on an Australiana campaign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to three matters in this evening's debate which, in accord with precedent set by previous speakers, has been wide ranging in nature. The first is really an extension of a discussion in which I took part on a matter of public importance-the tax file number system-some three or four weeks ago. Last week I had cause in this place to direct a question to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) about the non-fulfilment of the requirements of the legislation. As the House will recall, my original concern surrounded the decision by the Australian Taxation Office to post to Queensland, the Northern Territory and Western Australia in excess of a million letters containing tax file numbers. At that time it became apparent that the Taxation Office had been in grave error and had used information dating back to the early 1980s. As a result of that mass post-out-and the Tax Office admits to this-at least 60,000 letters went to people who were no longer resident at the address to which the letter was posted or who had, sadly, passed away. As a result at least 60,000 tax file numbers are likely to fall into wrong hands.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of my raising this matter with the Privacy Commissioner on 17 February, the Privacy Commissioner moved in on the Australian Commissioner of Taxation and had discussions with Mr Boucher about the methods his office was using. Unfortunately, in many ways, the Privacy Commissioner accepted Mr Boucher's word that the extent of the errors would not be repeated and that the Taxation Office had no alternative but to go ahead and complete the post-out to the remaining States in Australia. That post-out took place and, again, it is anticipated that about 60,000 letters have gone to persons who have either shifted from their previous address or passed on since the end of August last year.

What causes me great concern is that the carelessness has been repeated. Recently in this Parliament I spoke about the jerry builder approach of near enough being good enough. There are reports from the southern States of how tax file numbers have been included in incorrect envelopes, how they have arrived unsealed, how they have arrived for deceased persons and how they have arrived for persons who no longer live at a particular address. What galls me is the fact that the Taxation Commissioner is a pacesetter in Australia-a man who demands of every man and woman in this country that they make no mistake of any kind and, if they do, they will face penalties. I believe that under the present Government the bureaucracy can blunder and err and be treated totally different from ordinary men and women.

In Question Time last week I mentioned the requirements in the Income Tax Assessment Act. If the Taxation Commissioner judged-he has that right and I do not argue with it-31 March as representing inadequate time to ensure that everybody had their tax file number, there was a provision in section 202c (4) (b) of the Act requiring a proclamation to be made by the Governor-General of this country. That proclamation was to give a lawful standing to an extension beyond 31 March, but what did we get? On the twelfth hour we got a press release from Mr Boucher headed `Do not panic about numbers'. He said that the Taxation Office was stressing the need for a commonsense approach by employers and employees. So he was well aware of what he was doing. He actually issued a press release, but he did not put in place a proclamation. To my knowledge there is still no proclamation. So here we have the Taxation Office, the Commissioner included, acting in an illegal way. What does the Government do? Absolutely nothing. The Treasurer told us the other day:
. . . I am quite certain the Australian Taxation Office will advise me whether in its view an extension is warranted; and, if it is required to be fixed by proclamation, I would consider it.

A deliberate decision to extend was made, yet the proclamation was not made. I just ask: How can Mr Boucher continue to hunt and haunt every individual in this country and have people living in a state of fear in case they make a mistake, yet be so flippant and careless in his own approach to the law? He was gone from the moment of that big post-out because thousands of letters did not meet the first requirements of the Privacy Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of them were unsealed.

—Some of them were unsealed, as the honourable member for Deakin reminds us. I believe that people are ringing up the honourable member too to tell him about it. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) told me tonight that a journalist in Adelaide even received a letter with two tax file numbers, one belonging to another person. So she does not need any convincing about the reports of politicians. I am advised that there was a report of it in the Adelaide Sunday Mail on the weekend. I stress that Mr Boucher himself, who is wound up with a determination to crush every taxpayer who wittingly or unwittingly errs, has a staff of thousands but cannot even follow the requirements of law. I dispense with my anger and make an appeal to him on a man to man basis: if he cannot get it right, have mercy on those little people out there who do not have staff at their beck and call, who cannot afford the best accountants in the land to help them weave their way through the Income Tax Assessment Act. I appeal to him if he cannot get it right to be understanding and to be less relentless in the manner in which he treats the honest mistake makers. I am not here as a friend of those who deliberately break the law, but the approach that has been in place in the last couple of years-`I will teach them by a lesson that they will never forget'-is not a reasonable one.

SPEECH.PARA: We have watched Treasurer Keating in this place attack Opposition members for having been critical of senior public servants. One of the realities of life in recent times is that many senior public servants are behaving like politicians. They go around making the speeches that Ministers should be making; they take controversial lines. I submit that any public servant who wants to stick his neck out will get it chopped off. I appeal to the Bouchers of this world: Instead of bleating about being singled out, let them examine the role they have played, and haul off and leave it to the politicians to play the political game. As I said in this place a year or so ago, I was concerned then about the political game that the Taxation Commissioner was playing. I invited him to become a member of this Parliament-if he really had pent-up feelings and frustrations, to get out of that office, cut his salary in half and come here to join the boys and girls who have the responsibility for the political arguments. He is simply an administrator. I ask him to remember that.

On the Treasurer's criticisms of Opposition members, we are still witnessing the Australian Statistician conducting the household expenditure survey, which was not tabled in this Parliament. It was supposed to be tabled in the first half of last year; it was not. I set about causing difficulties because it was another instance of the bureaucracy not following the law. What distresses me is the lack of courage the Australian Bureau of Statistics has displayed in seeking to avoid admitting that it was wrong. It tabled that survey, which had been under way for three months at the end of September, and refused to admit that it did not comply with the law, and now pretends, because it did table the document halfway through the survey, that it has legitimacy and it even threatens the hundreds of people out there who say, `I won't do it'. Again, we have a case of one law for the people and another law for the bureaucracy. The legislation relating to surveys says that unless a survey is tabled before the Parliament it shall be conducted as a voluntary one, yet the Government condones the continuation of this survey, which is being conducted under the guise of having the force of law.

My final point is on a different matter. I hold up an object. It is a make-believe suppository. Mr Deputy Speaker, the smile on your face indicates that you knew exactly what I had in my hand. It is larger than a normal suppository. If we open it up we find a letter from the Department of Community Services and Health, the Department of the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), about the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. It was sent to every Australian doctor. When doctors opened up this huge package, which would have had printed on it `Postage Paid Australia'-or, alternatively, `Postage paid by the Australian taxpayer'-they found one sheet of paper and something for sticking on a telephone or on the wall to remind them which drugs had been taken off the pharmaceutical benefits list. I have been told that doctors' receptionists and so on have taken them home for their children to use as a pencil case.

This was all part of a campaign to soften up members of the public to believe that the Government's introduction of a generic system for the provision of drugs was good for them, that it was going to move them along nicely and that they would not suffer any ill effects. I wrote recently to every doctor in my electorate asking, `If you are a prescriber of the drugs that the Government is taking off the pharmaceutical benefits list because the companies have refused to budge on their price, please advise me what you think'. Twenty-two Moreton doctors wrote back indicating that they were prescribers of the drugs of the companies affected. They indicated that thousands of their patients-I use that in the collective sense-would be affected. That means thousands of my Moreton people, particularly the elderly, will be affected by these changes. Of the 22 responding, only one was prepared to state that none of his patients would be, to use the words that the respondents had an opportunity to choose, adversely affected. Five of the doctors wrote back saying that they would wait and see. But 16 of the 22 doctors said that their patients would be adversely affected.

I do not quite understand why the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) became so rigid in his approach to this. The Government said that as a result of the switch to generic drugs it would save at least $12m. It has probably spent $1m or $2m on the full-page advertisements that appeared in all the newspapers in Australia and on the suppositories that it posted out to doctors. It has probably spent a lot of that saved money already. I make the point that a socialist government, whether it be democratic socialist or straightout socialist-one can take one's pick-really has no right to be telling the medical profession what drugs it will or will not prescribe. If a doctor believes that a certain brand of drug is the best for his patient, all the Government is doing is hurting the patients when the Government proclaims that the doctor will no longer have a choice. The Government was really big-hearted when it said that if people were not prepared to use a generic equivalent they could buy the brand name they were originally using at full price.

As I am not a medical practitioner, I am in no position to judge, but I would be lacking in responsibility to the people I represent and, indeed, to all Australians if I did not raise this issue in this place. Two-thirds of the doctors in my electorate who prescribe the drugs state that there will be an adverse effect. I have been advised that some of the people were on generic drugs previously and that brands are not exactly the same. Just because they have the same ingredients, it does not mean that they are exactly the same. Some people were taken off the generic drugs and switched over to brand names. As a result of those switchovers the health problem which was dogging them was overcome. The Minister may have an ideological battle with what some company will charge for a drug or is prepared to set as its lowest price, but he should not make the people carry the penalty. That is exactly what the Minister has done.

I conclude by making a call tonight to Minister Staples to reassess what he has done, to allow the return of some or all of these drugs as quickly as possible and not to keep them off the market simply on the basis of being bloody-minded and thinking that Big Brother must win because the companies have held their ground. The Government's decision will also affect research in the future. No government has the right to do this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution to this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1988-89 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 I would like to concentrate on the appropriations for the Department of the Arts, Sport the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) and, in particular, on those appropriations associated with the sports portfolio. How unusual for me! The issue of sport and its economic impact in this country is an issue which I believe is extremely understated. Successive governments over many years have seen the need to provide incentives for Australians to develop inventions, to develop their positions in the arts, science, business and so on. But there has been a relative lack of desire on the part of governments to involve themselves in sport-that is, with the exception of the last six years, under the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Too often sport is seen, to coin a phrase, as a froth and bubble industry, something which people participate in but whose economic benefits are not great. That certainly is not the case. In recent years Commonwealth expenditure on sport and recreation has been about $40m per annum. As I have indicated, there certainly has been a marked increase in sports funding under this Government compared with what it was in the term of our predecessors. However, the figure represents less than one two-thousandth of Commonwealth outlays. There is a need for our Government to review the position and to look at increasing funding for sport, not only at the elite level but also at the participation level. It should also look at funding more facilities right round Australia so that our elite sports men and women and those in the general sporting community can have first class facilities to use to develop their sporting prowess.

A number of studies are being undertaken, both within DASETT and in the broad sporting community, of the economic impact of sport in Australia. Some preliminary findings of the studies make interesting reading. An economic impact study by DASETT has found that total government support for sport and recreation was about $900m in 1985-86. If we add proportional increases to that figure, it is well over $1 billion in today's terms. The break-up of how that money was raised and spent is interesting. Local government contributed 73.3 per cent of the total sports cake. State and Territory governments contributed 20.6 per cent. The Commonwealth came in at No. 3, a bronze medallist if you will, at 6.1 per cent. The figures reflect the contribution by local and State governments in the provision of facilities. One only has to go into any electorate in Australia to see the work that is being done by local councils in the provision of sporting ovals, football fields, hockey fields, tennis courts and so on to appreciate the investment that local government puts into sport. I recognise that and acknowledge it.

Similarly, over a long period we have seen State governments involved in sport. We have seen the development of a range of facilities in Sydney, Melbourne, Perth and elsewhere. In all cases, particularly if there has been an Olympic Games or a Commonwealth Games component-pending bidding, perhaps to host the sporting events appropriate to those facilities-or if there has been an event of national significance, the Commonwealth Government has kicked in its fair share to provide an appropriate level of support for the development of those facilities.

Unfortunately, over a long period regional sports facilities have not tended to attract a great deal of support from any level of government. I will give some examples from my own area. The Illawarra region has over a long period produced sporting champions in a variety of fields. One only has to look at the record books to see the rugby league champions. I know the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons) is familiar with this fact. There are also the swimming champions, the Australian women hockey players and so on who have come from the Illawarra region. All of those champions have been produced in the relative absence of first class sporting facilities.

I will take another example, from the field of basketball. We have a team competing in the National Basketball League, the Illawarra Hawks. They presently play in a stadium lovingly referred to as The Snakepit. If nothing else, it has atmosphere. In fact, that is probably the only thing going for it. It is the scourge of other teams visiting the place, not only because of its atmosphere but also because the crowd is so close to the players. The facility existed when I was a mere lad in Wollongong, playing basketball at high school.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not too long ago; that is quite recent.

—It was a couple of years ago. I will talk in terms of my father. The facility has been there for a long time. Changes have been made to it, but its potential as a fire trap and its ability to cope with the crowd that now wants to see the Hawks playing in the National Basketball League and so on are no secret.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a problem attracting sufficient funds to build an alternative facility which the Hawks can use. In Queensland there is no problem. The facility at Boondall was constructed with the help of State government money. It is being managed by a management organisation and is returning a profit. It is not simply used by the Brisbane Bullets; it is also used for other sporting and entertainment events, the latter being an important component of such facilities.

There are plans to develop a brand new stadium in Wollongong to meet the needs of the Illawarra Hawks and to serve as an indoor entertainment-sporting venue. The big problem is attracting sufficient capital resources to construct the facility. About $12m to $14m is necessary. The New South Wales Government is not the least bit interested in supporting such a facility in the Illawarra. Yet the Illawarra, which is the second city of New South Wales, which arguably was ravaged by the downturn in economic conditions in the early 1980s more than any other part of Australia, is for some reason not receiving its just recognition or reward in the provision of such facilities.

I might speculate on some of the reasons for this. It may well be that the present Government, in March 1988, did not win a seat in the swing that went against the incumbent Government of Barrie Unsworth and saw him out of office. I might speculate that the Greiner Government thought, `There is no value in putting anything in Wollongong. They are always going to vote Labor'. I might speculate that, therefore, we do not have much of a chance in getting any financial support from the New South Wales Government to help construct this facility. That is a shame, because not only would it be a brand new base for the Illawarra Hawks, enabling 8,000 fans to be seated in relative comfort, but it would also be a regional indoors sports-entertainment centre.

The centre would have the added benefit of enabling Wollongong to be an attractive venue for some of the major rock and entertainment shows that now come to Sydney. As I understand it, entrepreneurs are looking for a venue other than the Sydney Entertainment Centre to make it just that little bit more economically feasible to bring to Australia the likes of Poison, Michael Jackson or any of the other rock-and-roll people. I have to take my kids to Sydney to see them in action. I would much rather take them half a mile down the road to see them in Wollongong. These entrepreneurs are saying that if there was a second venue in Sydney's western suburbs or in Wollongong it might make it more viable to have those artists stay in Australia longer and give enjoyment to more people. But we cannot seem to get to first base. The State Government does not want to know about it, but more disappointingly the local community does not want to know about it.

We are talking essentially about a steel town that was built on the back of Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd. Unfortunately, the community is not prepared to get in and support the Hawks. The Hawks are having a terrible time getting a major sponsor in the National Basketball League. Two years ago, they finished third; they made the play-offs. Last year they were one game off finishing fifth. This year they could be more competitive if they were able to get a couple of more decent players. Notwithstanding, the Government and the local community have not thrown their full support behind this organisation. That then begs the question: what about the Federal Government's responsibility and role?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just about to take a point of order.

—They have all gone to the western suburbs.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the Minister takes note of the recommendations in the report called Going for Gold! to which I alluded earlier and which was tabled in the Parliament a couple of weeks ago. I hope that not only does the Minister take cognisance of that report and the recommendations contained therein, but so too do the money Ministers of the Government, because it is high time we saw an interjection of funds into things like sports facilities and other things contained in some of the recommendations of the report. I suggest that tied into that whole question, however, is a relationship that touches on social and economic factors. I believe, as I am sure does the honourable member for Gippsland because he actively participates as a sportsman first thing in the morning before he starts the day, that a healthy lifestyle which involves exercise will lead to lower costs for government. It increases people's fitness levels, which therefore reduces their need to medical care and so on in later life.

Medical and physical education evidence brought before the committee of inquiry to which I have referred verifies that very thing: people who participate in sport will enjoy life far more than those who do not. They will feel healthier and they will find some time later in life that their health costs will be lower. That has to be good for government, by saving government funds.

Again, I can only suggest to those people who say that funds should be directed only to areas such as science and the arts and not to sport that there is no difference between the pursuit of excellence in sport and the pursuit of excellence in the arts or the sciences. I see them as similar entities. When we take elite sportsmen and women and provide them with some support mechanism, employment opportunities, resources for training, travel to overseas competitions and the ability to do well in their sports, they provide role models for people in the community to get actively involved in those sports. I do not think that anyone could take exception to the fact that when Pat Cash, for example, won Wimbledon, tennis suddenly boomed again in Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Wayne, the Wollongong boy.

—It may well be that some people take a different view and suggest, as has been considered in a number of places, that rather than encourage people to participate in sport, all this does is turn us into a nation of `Norms', a nation of television watchers who sit in front of the television set. SPEECH.PARA: As I indicated at the start of my contribution tonight, it is my considered view that the amount of money which is made available by the Commonwealth Government to sport is not adequate. TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1988-89 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 bring into stark reality the consideration of the economic management of this country and the real problems we face. The long awaited details of tax cuts and wage-tax trade-offs which have been promised by the Government for about two years now will be made known to this House on Wednesday night. There is no doubt that in recent months there has been considerable conflict between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) on matters pertinent to the decisions which will be announced. The promised tax cuts will give the Government an opportunity to bring into line many of the unsatisfactory policies which have created the difficult economic climate in which the Government finds itself. It is hoped that the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will redress many of the problems that confront this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately for many people, tax cuts will not be a simple solution to the problem of cost rises. We have seen an enormous escalation in interest rates and health charges, prices increases across the board and a dramatic widening of the gap between income and living expenses. This can be redressed only if there is a positive change by the Government in its economic direction. The big issue will be the extent to which tax cuts and other decisions to be announced will reduce the gap to which I have referred.

In my electorate there are many people on fixed incomes. There are young people who are endeavouring to raise a young family or to buy or build their own home. They all face the same difficulty-the enormous cost escalation which has overtaken the capacity of people to do things that they must do and which are vital for the future of this nation and for the welfare of the ordinary person. Of course, the difficulty for those on fixed incomes, pensioners and those within the bracket very close to the tax exemption level is that they get no benefit from simple tax cuts or wage increases. There has to be consideration of the effects of what has gone wrong since the last Budget in the areas of the inflation rate, interest rates and the whole spectrum of enormous increases in costs.

In the last Budget the Treasurer promised a reduced consumer price index (CPI) figure. He said that by June that figure would be down to 4.5 per cent. Yet currently it is almost double that amount and it certainly will be nowhere near the forecast. The result of this is tremendous pressure on costs and tremendous difficulties for people on small incomes who are endeavouring to maintain a standard of living to which they are entitled. Unless there is a firm approach to these problems there is no doubt at all that we will have a continuation of that very unsatisfactory situation in which promises have been made but have not been fulfilled.

In addition to inflation, I also refer to interest rates, the CPI level and all the basics that are inherent in a Budget or in a substantial statement of the kind that we expect on Wednesday evening in this House-the kind of statement that was made in May last year and the previous May. On each occasion the statement was euphoric about success, what was being achieved and what the results would be. We heard a debate in this House this afternoon in which both sides of the issue were, I think, put fairly strongly, but I must say that the defence by the Government did not measure up to the real issues.

For example, let us consider what has happened in the matter of the tax take in the seven months following the beginning of this financial year. A report by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) says that the gross pay as you earn (PAYE) collections to the end of February was $2,685m or 17 per cent higher than the collections for the same period last year. Over the same period PAYE refunds were 1.7 per cent higher than for the same period of last year, showing very clearly that the tax take is up and there is no quid pro quo for the people who pay the tax. Collections of non-PAYE tax-in other words, individual taxation-represented $1,666m to the end of February, 7.9 per cent lower than last year. That discloses that incomes were down because of cost increases and because of the difficulty for people in that bracket to produce--

TALK.START.PARA: —The average family man.

—The average family man is caught very badly in the economic structure that this Government has created. Prescribed payments under the new system amounted to $847m, 38 per cent higher than for the same period in the previous year. Despite some reductions in the last Budget, the company tax take was 26.3 per cent higher than for the same period in the previous year. Then we come to a very significant figure-one that is astronomical in proportion. The collection of sales tax in the eight months to the end of February was $6,160m, 24.3 per cent higher than for the corresponding period in 1987-88. So the figures go on, through to customs duty collections and so on. The only reduction is in excise, because of the crude oil price fall, where there is a substantial drop, but that was expected and has previously been debated in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: Where does all this lead us? It leads us to the startling situation where there is an enormous increase in the tax take. We are now being promised tax cuts that will cost about $5 billion and the figure has been floated of another $1 billion to increase certain benefits for low income earners in the needy section of the community, making a total of $6 billion. But on the other side of the spectrum is the problem that we are not paying our way in productivity and this nation is facing a current account deficit likely to be more than 50 per cent higher than forecast by the Government. The inflation level is almost double the forecast and the level of external debt is dangerously high, causing an enormous increase in interest rates and many other difficulties for business and for the consequences of the productivity of this country and its recognition.

In the debate earlier today I did not hear any admission on the part of the Government that this country has lost its rating as a place to invest. I did not hear any recognition of some of the figures to which I have just alluded. This has been glossed over and the average person is the victim. If we are to have a wage package that is meaningful, surely the ACTU and the Government must recognise that reward for productivity is the only answer to the real dilemma that is facing this nation. Unless there is a move in that direction there will be a continuation of the problems which confront Australia. I mention one other pertinent figure, that is, that domestic demand is up by 8.2 per cent and the level of exports is down by 4 per cent. That means simply that the trend is the wrong way at both levels. That can only lead to a further deterioration in the balance of payments, a further difficulty in the matter of the value of the dollar, vis-a-vis the interest rate and all the rest of it, and the problems of the productive sector. Primary industry, for example, is carrying more than 50 per cent of the load in terms of the earning of export income and it is being throttled by this Government, rather than encouraged. Those are the dilemmas that the country faces, which are not being recognised. I trust there is at least some modest acknowledgment of this fact when the Treasurer makes his important statement on Wednesday evening.

Unless this is done and the economy starts to turn the corner and the nation gets around to recognising productivity as the goal and as a consequence of that productivity providing some reward for the people who bring it about, the economy will never get out of the trough that it is in. I say to those on the Government benches that this is a very critical period. It is no use playing politics and offering-as no doubt will occur-some kind of sweetener to the electorate, while the Government fails to address the real problems and fails to acknowledge that the country has a financial dilemma and that it is no use sweeping it under the carpet. The long-term future employment in this country and the long-term considerations of housing and welfare and of the means to enable the needy section of the community to be serviced depend on the structuring of the economy so that it comes out of the trough that it is in.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the effect of capital gains tax on housing?

—That was just one of the decisions that had to be reversed. Honourable members heard the Treasurer say as late as today that the difficulty in housing was the fault of the State governments and the high prices being paid. Why did those two things occur? It was because of the changes made in three successive Budgets and two mini-Budgets. If the Government had encouraged housing and the kind of development that could be done if there was a climate in which it was advantageous to invest at practical rates of interest which did not have to be supplemented in some way, and in which funds did not have to be stretched by State governments in supplying welfare housing, and if negative gearing had not been taken away, the housing situation today would be much better than it is. What was said by the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) in that respect was absolutely correct.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), drew attention to the need for more funds for sport in this country. I applaud that, but on the other hand I think the Government should fix the priorities with a little bit of reality. I say to the honourable member for Macarthur that it is all very well to talk about the need for more funds for sport, but let us think of just one of the ingredients. If there is funding of the sort to which he referred, let me remind him that there is not one cent for the disabled in the field of sport in this country. That I believe reflects very badly on the Government and those who have been responsible for administering sport in this country at the Federal level.

In the final few minutes available to me, I refer to some current issues. As all honourable members know, there have been disastrous floods on the east coast of Australia and when we talk about the appropriation of funds in this House there is a need to recognise some of the priorities that must be met. People who have been affected hope that the Federal Government will not be shrinking away from its responsibility in the matter of what it will cost to restore roads and bridges, to assist badly affected primary producers and to help those whose homes were flooded or who suffered other similar losses as a result of the cyclone and the very heavy flooding that occurred on the east coast in recent days. Too often a headline, a quick announcement and some inference that something is being done are the beginning and the end of recognition of this need. Flood mitigation and many other ongoing requirements should be given priority and that priority should be related to community needs and to productivity, as part and parcel of the good government and proper management of this country. Tragically, that is not a consistent approach on the part of this Government. I deplore the fact that it is so easy for the Government to make a statement that makes it sound as though all is well, but if one goes and looks at what is being achieved, it turns out to be otherwise.

Earlier I mentioned that primary industry needs to be given support to ensure that productivity is at the highest possible level, with one consideration basic to that. The prosperity of primary industry determines the nation's capacity to earn foreign exchange that is so badly needed by this Government and by every Australian. Every time one hears of disruptions in the beef industry, for example, currently occurring in abattoirs, increasing the nation's difficulty in maintaining contractual arrangements with the Japanese market, it reflects on and unfortunately reduces the nation's capacity for export earnings.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a time of good seasons.

—As the honourable member for Lyne reminds the House, this is at a time of good seasons. There is no room for this sort of thing. I say again that, if there are to be wage advantages, they should be fairly conditional on those who get wage increases and increments sharing the responsibility for productivity and consistency, particularly in the matter of supply to world markets of this country's goods and services. The same can be said, of course, about a range of other industries, of which the sugar industry is but one. Time does not permit me in this debate to traverse all of the aspects. Today the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) welcomed the decisions that had come from international negotiations flowing from the Cairns Round of trade talks. That is all very well. Members of the Opposition applaud that, but let honourable members remember that there is a 25 years' lead time before we achieve real results. That is a very long time in the life of any industry or any participant in that industry and certainly in the life of any individual farmer. In the meantime, the Government should assist primary industry so that it can in the long run take the advantages that the changed trade negotiations will make possible.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I remind the House that the financial structure of the nation is fundamental to every individual, and the responsibility which devolves upon the Treasurer and the Prime Minister to ensure fairness, equity and reality is very great indeed. I hope that what honourable members hear in this House on Wednesday night will answer in a practical way the needs of the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening I join this debate to congratulate the Government on the contribution that it has made to expanding higher education in this country and, in particular, to congratulate the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) on the recent statistics covering enrolments in higher education for this year. These figures were released on Thursday last and they show the highest growth rate in student numbers for 15 years. Full time enrolments this year are up by 24,600, an increase of almost 10 per cent. In addition, part time and external enrolments have increased. The number of students commencing courses has increased by 8.3 per cent to 182,000. The figures also show that more women than ever are now participating in higher education.

The Government has now delivered the first instalment of the additional places promised as part of the higher education package announced last year with the introduction of the higher education contribution scheme. Fifty thousand more places are to come over the next three years. The response to these additional places and the enrolment figures should silence the critics of the higher education contribution scheme. We all recall that last year predictions were made that this scheme would discourage potential students and drive enrolments down. Quite clearly, the opposite is the case.

The figures also call into question the Opposition's higher education policy. As far as I understand it, that policy consists of four elements: first, the abolition of the higher education contribution scheme; secondly, a freeze on the number of government funded places in higher education; thirdly, the imposition of a charge amounting to full fees for any additional places above those frozen; and, finally, a system of competitive entry for the limited number of free places.

On the evidence, any move to abolish the higher education contribution scheme clearly should be resisted because that scheme has been accepted. Its implementation this year has been reasonably smooth. I have some criticism. I have evidence that some institutions have been failing to make part timers aware of the option of deferred payment but, by and large, the implementation of that scheme has been reasonably smooth.

On the question of the Opposition's plan to freeze the number of government funded places, we have no information from the Opposition yet on what the base would be. Would it be the number of government funded places at the time of announcement, in other words, back in 1988; would it be the number now, that is, 451,000; or would it be the number at the time when the Opposition eventually wins office? If it is the last I expect that, by that time, the Opposition front bench will have passed on and, hopefully, we would have a new coalition policy. Certainly the Opposition could not maintain funding at current levels with its current policy.

The proposal to impose full fees for any additional places faces enormous difficulties. If the experience with Bond University in its first year is any guide at all, there is enormous difficulty in getting any enrolments in full fee paying courses. Bond University, despite an expensive advertising campaign, had great trouble in attracting numbers to those courses. The question of competition for free places means essentially that if students, irrespective of their circumstances, win a free place they pay nothing. Again, if they do not win a free place, irrespective of their financial circumstances, they pay the lot. The lot in these terms means, on average, around $7,000 a year for a tertiary course. Surely it is fairer for everybody to pay a little. Under the higher education contribution scheme they do that when they can afford it-that is, after graduation and not as an up-front payment. In that way all applicants can participate in the system on an equal basis. That is a fairer system and that is certainly the way the Government sees it. On all the evidence, that is the way students and the general population see it as well.

This evening I would also like to draw some attention to the Government's achievements in the technical and further education (TAFE) sector. While the major contribution for technical and further education rests with the States, nevertheless the Commonwealth provides substantial financial assistance in this field. In 1989 over $325m will be provided to the States for TAFE, subject to resource agreements. This year $180m will be provided in direct grants for improved infrastructure in TAFE, including five new colleges, additions to a further 57 colleges, $6m for child-care centres in TAFE, money for upgrading equipment, the provision of student residences and the building of centres for Aboriginal vocational programs. In addition, $127m will be provided in general recurrent grants, $4.2m will be provided for the advanced English for migrants program and $4.6m will be provided to promote adult literacy and numeracy.

Under this Government, participation in TAFE has grown steadily. Since we came to office an additional 150,000 students have taken their places in vocational courses in TAFE. There has been steady growth in all age groups except the 15 to 19-year-olds, for whom increased school retention has, quite naturally, caused a reduction in TAFE participation. Students in this age group have chosen increasingly to stay on and enjoy the benefits of full secondary eduction, to the point where almost twice as many students are proceeding to year 12 now as there were in the years before we took office.

Nevertheless, in the TAFE, unmet demand is a growing problem. It is difficult to measure unmet demand in TAFE because statistics vary from State to State. But, as an example, in Queensland last year an estimated 49,000 applicants were unable to gain places in TAFE colleges. There is certainly a problem in unmet demand in TAFE in my own electorate and it concerns, in particular, the Penrith College of Technical and Further Education. By way of background, the Penrith TAFE college was established 25 years ago. Last year it had an enrolment of 6,400. As one might expect, its accommodation is getting old. The college is suffering from a shortage of space. It occupies a relatively small site and the space available is not being used to the best effect, to the point where the college needs to lease space elsewhere in Penrith. But it is a very valuable and convenient site; it is only two minutes from the railway station.

For some time there has been an unstated but quite evident desire by the New South Wales TAFE authorities to sell this site, in spite of a very strong local view that Penrith college should be retained and modernised so as to keep the advantages of the central location close to public transport, which is particularly important for students without their own transport. The advantages are obvious, especially for female students using the college at night. This question of the future of the college arose during the State election campaign last year and the then Labor member for Penrith, Peter Anderson, met with students and with the staff of the college and settled the question very quickly. However, there have been a number of recent developments which are of importance. After the election of the Greiner Government in March last year the rumours persisted that the desire of the New South Wales TAFE authorities was to dispose of the college and to sell the site. Those rumours intensified and became increasingly important in the local community.

By way of response, in November last year the college committee under its Chairman, Allan Fisher, produced a very important document entitled College Profile and Five Year Plan. It is a very good document that spelt out in some detail the needs of the local community and the role that the Penrith College of TAFE should play in meeting those needs. At the same time, in November last year, the college committee issued an important document entitled Penrith City's College of TAFE-An Investment in the Future. This shorter document gave details of the achievements of the college over the last 25 years: the fact that it had prepared in that time more than 75,000 students for their working lives; the contribution that the college had made to the work skills base; the college's social investments in terms of its work in adult literacy, in training of the deaf, and in its English as a second language classes; and the contribution that the college had made to the programs of other agencies, including the Commonwealth Employment Service, the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service, the Department of Social Security, the Department of Community Services and Health, the New South Wales Department of Corrective Services and the Foundation for Disabled. The college has done an excellent job in servicing the needs of all those organisations. For example, for many years the college has conducted cookery and catering classes for the trainees at the New South Wales Department of Corrective Services' establishment at Emu Plains. It has been my pleasure to go along to the graduation dinners where, after a six-week cookery class, the trainees have put on a very nice evening, with some entertainment and a pleasant meal, for local guests. So the college is doing a great job for the local community.

The document also argued that the efficient and equitable delivery of services depended on the retention of the central site that I mentioned. In the words of the statement, the site represents a commitment of those who work in Penrith; it is convenient for those who work in Penrith; and it provides assistance for those who rely on the nearby public transport systems to get to their classes. The statement was circulated among the local community for endorsement. A number of people in the local community signed it, including people from local industry, the Chamber of Commerce, local banks and building societies, the local council and a whole range of government agencies. Local members of parliament also signed the statement in support of the college. Local State members, including Tony Aquilina, the local member for Mulgoa; Anne Cohen, the Liberal member for Minchinbury; Kevin Rozzoli, the Liberal member for Hawkesbury and Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, signed the statement, as did I. Unfortunately, there was one notable exception and that was the Liberal member for Penrith, Mr Guy Matheson. He declined to sign the statement. Even when pressed to sign it, he refused to do so.

It was at that stage that the plot began to thicken, because I think that Mr Matheson may have seen the writing on the wall as it was in February this year that the New South Wales Education Minister, Dr Metherell, released a discussion paper entitled Future Options for Penrith College of TAFE. That future options paper consisted of a preamble and eight options for the future of the college. The preamble is an unremarkable piece of work. It details things that locally we all know, such as that there is great population growth in the region and that there is considerable growth in the labour force in the region. The local labour force has more than doubled in the last 15 years. The preamble mentions government priorities which, again, are beyond criticism. The State Government is committed, the document states, to increasing educational opportunities and widening educational choice in the region. The preamble also details the important challenge facing the college. Currently there is a local unmet demand of 5,000-5,000 people who applied last year could not be admitted-plus 25,000 who have been identified as living in the region but who have to travel to colleges in the inner city because the courses that they choose are not available locally. So there is a direct unmet demand of 5,000 plus a potential additional 25,000. Finally, the preamble to the options paper mentions the demand on the three existing TAFE facilities in the outer west. Those existing facilities consist of three small colleges of which Penrith is the largest.

On reading the preamble of the options paper, one sees that it makes an excellent case for the provision of an expanded and modern college at Penrith. The eight options which follow the preamble are, therefore, a major disappointment. Option 1 is essentially for the status quo with a minor upgrading: it is the no change option. Options 5, 6, 7 and 8 are variations on a common theme and rely on the transfer of courses and students out of Penrith and into other colleges: in other words, they are four options for the disposal of Penrith TAFE. Option 2 is for the redevelopment of the current site by 1994 at a cost of $28m but to accommodate only 600 extra students. Option 3 is for the redevelopment of the current site, plus the adjoining site, at a cost of $46m to accommodate 1,600 extra students by the year 2012. Option 4 is for the disposal of the current site and development of a new college on a new site at a cost of $42m to provide 5,600 extra places by the year 2012. The assumption on which the options are based is that there will be no change over that time in the availability of State and Commonwealth funds and no change in existing State and Commonwealth spending priorities.

The paper offers no background to the costings, so it is difficult to assess their validity. However, I would make three points: first, a simple subtraction of option 2 from option 3 would reveal that, while redevelopment of the existing site is estimated at $28m, the purchase and development of an equivalent area next door is estimated to cost only $18m. The conclusion to which I am drawn is that the $28m for the redevelopment of the college on the existing site is a very much inflated figure. Secondly, the $42m for option 4, which involves the purchase of a new site and the sale of the present and very valuable site, is presumably a net figure-that is, inclusive of the proceeds of the sale of the existing site. That is also probably an inflated figure. Finally, the estimate for the construction periods extending to the year 2012 in options 3 and 4 is also an inflated figure. Therefore, I suggest that the options paper for the future of Penrith College of TAFE is a loaded document. It has been loaded in favour of the disposal of this valuable property by the New South Wales Government in favour of a decision which will disadvantage the local community and, in particular, those students who use public transport to get to courses after working hours.

In conclusion, I offer Dr Metherell another solution. As his own options paper says, 25,000 students from the region travel to inner city colleges because they cannot obtain the courses that they follow locally. I suggest to Dr Metherell that he sell one of those inner city colleges and use the proceeds from the sale to construct a modern, expanded college in Penrith to meet the needs of this important, growing community. There are plenty of parallels in recent experience. One can remember Laurie Brereton, when Minister for Health in New South Wales, spearheading the beds to the west campaign, closing down wards and hospitals in the inner city to open up wards and provide additional beds in hospitals in the outer west where the people are. This Government has followed a similar policy by agreeing to fund the proposed University of Western Sydney in my electorate to bring higher education places close to where the students are and to build up that institution into a great university closer to the centre of population development in Sydney.

Certainly, a movement in TAFE places would achieve a solution to the problem that I have gone through in some detail in the House tonight. It has been done with hospital beds. We are doing it as well with higher education places. I believe that the New South Wales Government should do it with TAFE. It can be done. It should be done by Dr Metherell in New South Wales to benefit those many people in my electorate who travel to inner city colleges at the moment. It is a disgrace that the New South Wales Government should be considering closing down a TAFE college in an area which so desperately needs the provision of extra places.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I devoted an entire speech last week to the wrong-headedness of the Government's higher education policy, I will not attempt to take up in detail some of the comments made by the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free). Rather, I will move to the immediate subject matter--
