These inevitably raise the central issue of the Government's economic policy. This debate is taking place in the immediate run-up to the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) this Wednesday night on the wage-tax package. A genuine trade-off of tax cuts for a lesser wage rise was a central feature of the Treasurer's last August Budget strategy. But in realistic terms what we will hear about on Wednesday night is the `best' package acceptable to the unions; that is, to the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the union arm of this ALP-ACTU Government-the bribe in short to keep the unions cooperative until after an election to be brought on as soon as possible after the 1 July tax cuts, which are part of the package, come into effect.

SPEECH.PARA: What we will not hear about is that, in the current state of play-that is, the failure of the Treasurer's economic policy-even the minimum package available in this sense will increase disposable incomes quite significantly and thus, with the Government committed to a high interest rate policy as the sole tool of economic policy, will require interest rates to rise still further. A housing mortgage interest rate of 17 per cent and even 18 per cent, as was suggested by the shadow Minister for finance, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), this afternoon, is already being talked about. That would mean an increase of 4 1/2 percentage points, from 13 1/2 per cent to 18 per cent, in the home mortgage rate over the past 12 months. That would add of the order of $70 a week to the average mortgage of $80,000. All that is in the context of this morning's news that house mortgage repayments are taking 40 per cent of the gross income of the average Sydney household. The cost of mortgage repayments is already up $40 a week. In that sense the average Australian has been hit in advance, so to speak, for tax cuts of the princely order of $20 a week on average. So we will get tax cuts, but interest rates will then be jacked up further by this Government. What is given by the one hand will be taken away by the other, or by several hands at once, as my colleague put it this afternoon, as there follows a renewed impetus to inflation, as tax is clawed back by bracket creep, and so on.

I talked a moment ago of this Treasurer's failed economic policies, but it is not just me, as an Opposition member, who has done so. I want to recall to the House some of the headlines of recent weeks. Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald in mid-February made a front-page criticism of the Government's policy with the headline, `Keating has lost control'. Mike Steketee at the same time put it as follows: `Suddenly, Paul Keating, the master strategist, has no new answers, only excuses'. Michael Stutchbury more recently in the Australian Financial Review referred to `The Hawke Government's bungled economic strategy'. In another article just a few weeks back under the heading `What Keating is doing wrong', Ross Gittins further wrote:
Mr Keating's last [year's] strategy has collapsed.
`Collapsed' is a very strong word. He went on:
But if he knows his strategy has failed, he isn't admitting it.

That is very true. We are smothered under a mass of disinformation, as my colleague the shadow Minister put it-or the same thing, not telling it as it is, irresponsibly for low-and by that I mean imminent election-reasons. But not telling it as it is compounds the failure and prejudices a proper attack on the nation's problems. I cite also Professor Barry Hughes, former personal economic adviser to the Treasurer. After an exhaustive analysis of the balance of payments figures for the finance house First Boston Australia Ltd, Hughes concluded that the economic outlook as seen from the perspective of the balance of payments is much worse than the Government has indicated. He wrote:
The underlying annualised deficit is probably in the vicinity of $16.75 billion-clearly well beyond the bounds of sustainability.

Of course it is. It amounts to this country going further into hock every day to the tune of $50m-from this time yesterday till now, an extra $50m into hock. That level of profligate living beyond our means and borrowing from foreigners or selling them the farm is just not on.

The patently failed policies of the Treasurer, for which he bears a heavy responsibility-though in his campaign of disinformation he blames just about everyone or everything but himself-is sufficiently evidenced by two statistics. The first is the massive balance of payments deficit to which I have just referred-$14, $15 or $16 billion for 1988-89 compared with the $9.5 billion laid down in the last August Budget. The Treasurer has not much credibility left. The second statistic is the resurgence of inflation-7 to 8 per cent as measured by the consumer price index and over 9 per cent as measured by the implicit price deflator of the recent national accounts. This is the highest level in the industrialised world just when, as the House will readily appreciate, in order to trade our way out of the balance of payments situation we need a lower price-cost structure than our trading partners, not a higher one, so that our export products will sell better and more profitably and we can compete more effectively with imports.

The massive balance of payments deficit is in part the result of the evident overheating of the economy-building and construction, motor vehicles and other sectors all going at it too strongly-but that in itself owes much to the political manipulation of interest rates by the Treasurer in the context of the 1987 election and again in the latter part of 1987 through to the New South Wales election in March of 1988. But what has happened? The Government is making no serious effort to cool the situation via fiscal policy; that is, via reducing its own expenditure. That is too hard. I see the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) is in the House. He should not tell me that this cannot be done. I just recall for the House the statement made by his colleague the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. He referred to:
. . . 200 bloody programs-
the French is his-
that can't be justified on social justice, equity or economic efficiency grounds . . .

which could be cut. I repeat that the Government does nothing in terms of reducing its own spending to cool the situation and, further, it encourages expectations of tax cuts and wage increases. The Government is obliged in that context to fall back on a high interest rate policy-monetary policy-as the sole tool of so-called macro-economic policy. But that fouls it all up. The Hawke Government and the Treasurer go for very high interest rates to slow the economy. The high interest rates, apart from their adverse impact on individuals, damage the economy by pushing up the Australian dollar and making Australian industry less competitive, adversely affecting much needed exports and import-competing Australian production. They also damage the economy by cutting into business investment. In that context I would say that recent optimistic investment figures, especially those relating to expected investment, reflect earlier times of lower interest rates and higher confidence and will come off the boil soon enough in the face of ever higher interest rates.

That is how the Treasurer's policy has fouled up. The impact of it all on Australians is, as the measure the Opposition has put forward indicates, that a family on average weekly earnings would require in the order of $58 a week extra to restore the same level of living that applied in 1983 when this Government came to power. That is the impact on the taxpayer, who is taxed to the eyeballs, one might say, and shafted by these high interest rates.

All of this is in the area of so-called macro-economic policy, policy for the economy as a whole, basically managing total demand in the economy. But tied in with it is the Labor Party's failure-its very incapacity, I will come back to that-to address so-called micro-economic policy, that is, needed structural change and increased market efficiency. That is what we are talking about there. In simple terms, one can say that this area of policy is all about the freeing up of supply, supply increasing, increasing productivity and total production. Though it is longer term, this nevertheless is where important emphasis needs to be in all of this. If we have too much demand, the first and immediate response is to reduce total demand-in the so-called macro area. But it is a more constructive, more beneficial and, ultimately, less painful exercise to think in terms of freeing up, increasing supply, increasing productivity, that is, the output per person and therefore total production. That, I repeat, is what so-called micro-economic policy, is all about.

There are many aspects of policy in this area. I nominate, first, the labour market. There is an urgent need to free up the rigid, inflexible, centralised Australian wages and industrial relations system.

The imperative necessity for this nation in order to secure its future is to produce more, but ourselves to consume less, saving more, at all events for a time, and in effect sell the difference overseas. That is what is needed. Privatisation is about expanding Qantas and Australian Airlines; about creating jobs in those enterprises; and about giving employees a say in the running of the organisations by giving them the opportunity to be owners of shares in the corporations. But the honourable member opposite has a pathological hatred of workers owning a share in business because he comes from the intellectually dead Socialist Left.

The only exciting political ideas of this decade are those of the Right, because the Left is intellectually dead and bankrupt. It does not know where to go, as the honourable member opposite showed. The Socialist Left has been deserted in part by the Right in its own government, but the Right is crippled by the power of the Socialist Left and by the power of the trade union movement, so the Government is going nowhere. It is indeed the Opposition that has set the intellectual agenda, created the philosophical climate and developed the exciting new policies going in a new direction for Australia in the 1980s. As we move to the 1990s these are the policies that Australia needs: privatisation of government enterprises such as those to which I just referred, deregulation of the Government sector, and freeing up the free enterprise markets so that businesses can operate free of government interference and government restriction.

The community, business and employees need a flexible industrial relations policy under which small businesses in particular, are not bound by a centralised wage fixing system over which the small business owner and the small business employee have no control. They want to be free to reach their own bargains and make their own deals-their own small business enterprise based agreements concerning wages, terms and conditions of employment, rostered days off and leave. They want to do that free of centralised control-free from a centralised wage-fixing system and centralised deals done by the Government with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). Those are not the types of restrictions that small business wants or needs.

This side of politics has set the intellectual agenda and has created the climate in Australia for a move to policies that give freedom to individuals to operate at all levels of the economy. The Government is bogged down. It has borrowed some of our ideas-I guess that is a compliment-but it is bogged down in the area of so-called micro-economic reform. It cannot do anything about the waterfront. Last week some figures were released showing that $630m-odd could be saved in the area of exports if there was reformation on the waterfront. But the waterfront unions went along to the ACTU and the ACTU said that there could be no reforms on the waterfront. The waterfront is vital to exports and imports. It goes without saying that exports are our lifeblood in earning overseas income. The added costs of the waterfront are enormous, but we will not see any tackling of this problem by the Government. We have not seen the Government tackle the high cost of shipping on the Australian coast, again an enormous cost to the Australian economy and one which helps make us uncompetitive among other nations in the global trading world. This is a government that can go no further in the field of deregulation because union bosses have put up their hands and said `No'. It is a government that is crippled, tired and worn out; it has just run out of time.

The one area in which the Government is doing enormous harm is what should be the dynamic area of small business. The small and medium sized business or enterprise in Australia should be the lifeblood of the economy. Small businesses and the people who own and run them, the small entrepreneurs-from the milk bar two or three doors from my office to the small manufacturing business, farming and businesses in rural and regional towns in Australia-are the backbone of this great nation. In the past small business has been a great contributor to employment growth. I read that small business has generated some 70 per cent of the private sector jobs created in the last four years. We will not get growth in the public sector, and we will not get it in the large corporate sector, basically because it is cutting back or rationalising its numbers. The future of this country lies in a dynamic and prosperous small business sector. That is the future of Australia and it is under threat and attack today.

The major threat to small business today is the enormously high interest rates it is charged by the banks and others from which it has to borrow for its capital requirements and working capital. High interest rates are hurting small business. Throughout the land, small business is the first to feel the effect of and the first to be squeezed by high interest rates. High interest rates are biting into profits; they mean that there will not be investment by small business. It is only through such investment that we will get the job creation so necessary for a dynamic Australia. What this Government is doing to small business is a tragedy. In the 24 March edition of the Business Review Weekly I saw that the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, which is inquiring into small business, the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), said that the Committee had pinpointed two main areas for change: in the sales tax regulations and collections and in capital gains tax. That is an interesting admission and I hope that the Committee reports in that way. Its Chairman is reported as saying that the sales tax regulations have resulted in enormous bottlenecks for small business and the capital gains tax has created enormous confusion. I congratulate this Government member on his admission about the effect of sales tax and capital gains tax on the small business sector.

Let me deal first with sales tax. The regulations need to be made simpler and less confusing. At a time of high interest rates it enables us to focus on the real need for reform in the Sales Tax Act when the small business proprietor or owner of an individual enterprise has to pay sales tax within 21 days. In these days of high interest rates, squeezes and debtors not paying on time-in fact going from 30 to 60, 90 or even 120 days to pay-the squeeze for working capital is on the small business which has to go to the bank and borrow at high interest rates. That business has to borrow in order to pay the sales tax which is payable in 21 days when the business will not be paid for 60 or 90 days. In some cases if the debt is $1,000 or $2,000 that small business may have to wait a year because many debtors know that it is not worth that small business going to court to sue for such an amount. It would cost more than the debt was worth to do so.

That is the situation in which small business is placed. There is a need for urgent reform of the sales tax system, which is grossly unfair, especially in relation to the small business sector. Payment of sales tax within 21 days may have been a reasonable requirement 30, 40 or 50 years ago when everyone paid his debts on time but, as the nature of business and of payment by debtors has changed, sales tax legislation has remained fixed and firm and it definitely needs changing.

The other area to which the Chairman of the Committee referred in a statement in the Business Review Weekly of 24 March is that of capital gains tax reform. I could not agree more. I refer to a submission by the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, known as COSBOA, and an Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) Budget overview submission. I agree with the point it makes when it calls for `the goodwill gained from the sale of a business to be exempt from capital gains tax if rolled over as start-up or working capital in another business within 12 months, or into a retirement benefit fund'.

COSBOA is pointing to the plight of small family businesses or family farms where all members of the family work enormously long hours-no 40-hour week for them, no rostered days off, no maternity leave, none of the other benefits that their employees might get. They work their guts out to make a living for the family to benefit Australia and, in doing those long hours late into the night and at weekends, they build up the business and increase its value. In fact, the value of that business in many ways is wages or salaries forgone for them. The time and effort that they have put in on weekends, late at night and after hours have built up the capital of that business because income forgone becomes capital. Then the business is subject to the capital gains tax provisions of this Government.

That is a matter that I raised at the time the capital gains tax legislation was brought in by this Government and it is an anomaly that needs fixing. It is a disincentive squarely facing the small business sector. Clearly, it discriminates against the small business sector and is a disincentive to investment and to people to work hard to build up a business, sell it and pay tax at the top marginal rate on the capital gain on that business. For example, if a person has a franchise on a 7-11 store, local milk bar or small manufacturing business and has worked hard he or she may pay capital gains tax on the goodwill of that business that has been built up over the years. I think that is absolutely outrageous.

As I have mentioned, interest rates are hurting and squeezing small business today. There is an urgent need that the small business sector get relief by the Government's bringing into place policies that allow a low interest rate regime in Australia. The interest bill saps the entrepreneurial spirit and confidence of small businesses.

In the limited time available I will just refer to suggestions about corporate tax changes. Taxpayer, a publication of the Australian Taxpayers Association, in May last year pointed out the possibility of and the potential for company tax changes that lift taxable incomes with tax rate cuts and offsets only for companies and discriminate against individual taxpayers who run small businesses. In fact, the individuals who are paying tax at the higher rates will be hit by a double whammy. That is why there is an urgent need for tax rates in this country to be reduced to create incentive across the board, especially for those individuals who do not have a corporate structure in running a small business. We need productivity in this country. We are losing productivity-that is, the efficiency with which we produce goods and services. We are falling behind and the Government's centralised approach will make that worse.

I conclude by saying that this Government's wage-tax deal will get us nowhere. It will be destroyed by inflation because by June next year the average Australian on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children will still be at least $50 per week worse off than when the Hawke Government came into power-an indictment of this Government and an indication of its failed policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say I always enjoy listening to the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton). He comes up with some lulus from time to time and, with all due respect to him, I must say his arguments were somewhat convoluted tonight. He gave the perfect example of why there should be a capital gains tax. He told this House that small business people worked long hours and did not take the effort of work value at the time by way of income which would have been taxable. Rather, the income accumulated by the way of capital. Somehow the honourable member then suggests that, if one can achieve this by way of a taxation system, capital therefore should not be treated as income at the time the business is sold. I have never heard a better reason for the imposition of a capital gains tax given in this House. For many people, capital is income. It goes back to the basis of the share market when only a few years ago major institutions had the opportunity to cause a run on a particular share, increase the value of those shares, then sell on the market, make many millions of dollars profit by way of capital gain and pay no tax on it. This afternoon I heard the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) say that the coalition parties, when they come to government, will abolish the capital gains tax. I suggest that it would be wonderful to see them try to do that. Also they would abolish the fringe benefits tax. What about the assets test; will they abolish it as well?

SPEECH.PARA: It is suggested that the coalition parties, if elected to government, will write off a billion dollars of revenue and at the same time they will cut Commonwealth expenditure and somehow they are going to cut taxes further than we are going to do. If any person with a reasonable degree of intelligence sits back and analyses what members of the Opposition are saying, he will find that they are going to take over a billion dollars from revenue and cut taxes further than the Government proposes to do, which further reduces revenue, and at the same time they will cut the revenue base, and yet somehow Australian families will be better off. That, surely, is the most magical wand that has ever been waved in this place. God help the nation if ever the coalition parties get the chance to put their proposals into practice, because they will not work.

I have listened to many speeches in the last couple of days when the Appropriation Bill was being debated and have heard a lot of nonsense about small business, for the most part from people who have never been small businessmen-people who never ran a small business. The honourable member for Higgins, I gather, was a corporate lawyer who worked for a large corporate organisation. The honourable member for Mayo, on the other hand, was a public servant. Those honourable members come into this House whingeing about small business, never having conducted one in their life, never having been on the ground. Let me tell them, I have been there and I have done it. I know what I am talking about.

Members of the Opposition talk about the predatory practices of government and the regulations of government. When they do, we on this side of the House sit back and smile. Why are there regulations? Why has this Parliament-not just this Government-over the last two decades regulated business and regulated the marketplace? Why have all governments in this country done that? At the moment I am a member of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which is inquiring into insider trading. We have taken evidence from various commercial organisations and business representatives who are calling for further regulation of the securities market. At the same time, members of the Opposition say they are going to get rid of all the regulations, while business in this country-including small business-says to this Parliament clearly, `We want more regulation of the securities market because insider training is rife. It is wrong. The only way to stop it is for this Parliament to pass laws to regulate the industry even further'.

If honourable members opposite stop and think about it, the reason that business men are saying that to this Parliament is that they want the playing field level and the market will not level it by itself. The so-called free enterprise system that is so often bandied about this place is a nonsense. It may be written up in all the textbooks. Honourable members can read John Stuart Mill, Adam Smith and all the rest of the economists of the eighteenth century; they can look at the laissez faire system and find the South Seas bubble, of course, and they will find Salomon's case when the companies were first established as a principle and since then every government in the world has passed regulations in an attempt to make the so-called free enterprise system work. That is why we regulate. It is not because anyone on this side of the House or on the other side believes that regulations per se are desirable.

God help the country should the day ever come when some magical means is found of tearing up all the regulations that this Parliament has passed since 1901 and all the regulations State parliaments have passed, and getting rid of them all. Members of the Opposition know and I know and everyone in this place knows, as the marketplace knows, that there would be chaos and there would be predatory practices. Small business would be decimated by the big players. The securities industry would be full of rogues and criminals. The banks would take over and there would be no marketplace. The economy would be hopeless. That is the reality and that is why parliaments throughout the world regulate. We need to be very careful about how we regulate, but we need to do it.

What is the Trade Practices Act for? It is a regulation. It is to try to make a fair and free marketplace. It is trying to level the playing field for small business and big business. It is trying to make the playing field level for consumers as against corporate practices which are demonstrably wrong, and no-one on the other side of the House would disagree with that. No member of the Opposition says that the Government should get rid of the Trade Practices Act and its regulations which are passed as a result of that Act.

Why did this Parliament pass the security regulations? It was because neither the Government nor the private sector trusts the predatory practices of the securities industry. Business wants that sort of legislation. Business comes to this Parliament and says, `There are wrong things occurring in the securities industry. Pass laws and regulate it'. So we do it, to try to level the playing field-often not terribly successfully. Why does the Government have company laws? Why increasingly since Salomon's case have countries throughout the world with monotonous regularity passed more and more increasingly complex legislation and regulations to try to level the playing field, to try to make business operate within a fair and competitive environment? That is why this country has company laws and company regulations.

The States have health Acts and health Act regulations enforced by local government and health inspectors. Why do governments pass such laws? It is because, if they do not, they know that there are enough people out there in the free enterprise market, the marketplace, who will sell foodstuffs that will kill, items which can damage and destroy Australian families. Honourable members know that, because it is happening. So we pass health Acts and we pass regulations under the health Acts. No-one complains about that. Why should they? It is done to assist Australian families to survive in a very predatory area.

I have heard a lot about taxation laws in the last couple of days from Opposition spokesmen. Why do we have such complex laws today and why do we have such complex regulations? Why was it necessary to legislate for the fringe benefits tax? Why was it necessary to increase the powers of substantiation? It was because the people out there were rorting the system, because it was not a fair taxation system that the Labor Government inherited. It was a system under which wage earners were paying 80 per cent of total tax revenues in this country, while large corporate raiders were paying no tax. Honourable members tend to forget that, while Labor has been in office, corporate tax revenues have increased by 24 per cent in the last 12 months. The Government is now collecting a fairer proportion of taxes from those people who, if there were not increased taxation laws and regulations, would pay no tax. The current inquiry by a standing committee on the use of tax havens by Australian companies is demonstrating again-if it ever needed to be demonstrated-that the so-called free enterprise people, the so-called market people who want level playing fields, will rort the system if they get the chance.

Let us face it; the marketplace is not a very nice place to be in. Sometimes I hear honourable members come into this House with whingeing voices. I do not accuse the honourable member for Higgins of that. I have never heard him whinge. But when I hear the tones of the people over the radio they sound very whingeing indeed. As I said, I hear honourable members whingeing and complaining about what this Government is doing to small business, and those members never put their mouth and their money where there principles lie. They are people who have taken the easy path through life. They have never gone out and tried to make a living sitting in an office by themselves, having borrowed money and employed people. When I hear that, I really wonder what the Opposition is up to and I wonder about the capacity of members of the Opposition to understand small business.

I was not going to talk about those matters. But having listened to some of the speeches I think it is time that we tried to get a rational debate about where we are going as a country. We should not sit back in this place day after day, night after night and hour after hour dealing with the Appropriation Bills listening to nothing other than negativism. I have not heard one positive suggestion from honourable members on the other side of this chamber as to which they are doing since the Appropriation debate started. I have heard a lot of whinges and a lot of complaints.

We tend to forget that honourable members opposite had 30 years in government. So if they say that we are wrong a lot of that blame can be carried forward from them. Despite the whinges, the complaints and the howls day in and day out, it is impossible to get any debate with them. We cannot even debate tax with them because they will not tell us what their tax policy is-if they have one. We cannot debate the economy with them because they will not tell us what their fiscal policy is-if they have one. We cannot debate deregulation with them because we do not know what they mean when they talk about regulation and we do not know what their policy is-if they have one.

They come into this chamber day in and day out and we are quite happy and prepared to debate issues with them in a rational way. They have never put a policy or a positive statement on the table about what they would do in those areas. Frankly, I can say, after four years in this place, that it is no wonder that they sit on the Opposition benches. I can say quite frankly to any person who is listening to this speech or who will read it down the track that it frightens the pants off me to think that it is ever possible that some of those people opposite could actually sit on the Treasury benches. Frankly, it really worries me.

In the past I have had respect for many of the present members of the Opposition when they were in government. I think some Liberal governments have achieved quite wonderful things. In my youth I was a Menzies fan. I must confess that in recent times, having studied that period, I wonder where we went wrong. We must go back to that period and ask why the Government of the day had no policy for the future. Nevertheless, I certainly had respect for the Menzies era. It is very hard when we come into this place and listen to the carping, whingeing people on the other side refusing to put a policy on the table and refusing to debate an issue to have much respect for them and to have any real belief that they have anything that they can offer to the Australian people.

Let us take the trade debate. Any person who thinks about it seriously realises that our future lies in Asia. I see people waving the Australian flag; I hear people talking about Future Directions, which is historical, and I hear people talking about the past as they bandy Margaret Thatcher around the place. But the reality is that the British joined the European Economic Community (EEC) and they dumped this country economically. The British dumped us in the trade area and they took the path, which no doubt suits them, and I do not criticise them for that. But that era is over for this country.

The Americans are not the least bit interested in Australia as a country unless it suits their own purposes. Anyone in this House who thinks that the Americans will necessarily do this country a favour really has rocks in his head and I say that without criticising the United States. Why should the United States bend over backwards? We are of no great interest to it except as a defence base and a handy ally around the place. If it comes to the economic crunch the Americans will not give two bob for us and they will dump us and look after their own trade interests if it suits their purposes. The Japanese buy from us because we are a suitable and a handy market and we have the resources available.

Asia is growing at an enormous rate. By the year 2000, Taiwan, South Korea and Thailand will each have seen huge growth, far beyond even average Asian growth rates. The wealthy segment of their populations will be larger than Australia's total population. Many of us have been to Thailand in particular and we know what is happening there. I will relate an incident which occurred at Christmas when I was having lunch with a shareholder of the Bangkok Bank-a very lovely, intelligent lady who was educated at a private school in Sydney. I might add that this bank is entering into joint ventures in Australia. It is interested in investing in Australia and it is interested in joint ventures in Thailand with Australian companies. Over lunch that lady asked me about Australia's apartheid policy. How embarrassing it is for an Australian politician to sit in a foreign country, to be hosted for lunch by an intelligent woman educated at a private school in Australia and to be asked about Australia's apartheid policy. Frankly, the debate last year on Asian immigration has unarguably done this country great harm in an area where, undoubtedly, our future trade and economic interests lie. The tragedy still is that people like Mr Ruxton are being quoted in the Bangkok press, in the English language newspapers. Even when I was there at Christmas Mr Ruxton was reported in the English language Bangkok Post.

I sometimes find it strange that people live in the past. I can understand why many Australians have very strong views about some Asian countries. I happen to take an interest in the Second World War. Whilst I was too young to participate in it, I would suggest that I know my Second World War history better than most other Australians in my age group. I visited Hellfire Pass and I understand why any person who put time in in the Hellfire Pass and on the Thai-Burma railway would be very unforgiving about what occurred to them for the rest of their lives. I do not blame them, but I did not experience that. I represent a country that has to recreate trade in a world which is distorted and changing. Those people who do not understand that this country has to stand independently on its own two feet and seek new friends around the world and not rely upon our traditional sources of trade unfortunately are living in the past and, regret- tably, will always live in the past.

I firmly believe that, if we are to survive as a nation, it is time that we looked to Asia; it is time that Australian businessmen learnt languages; it is time that Australian business men and women learnt about Asian culture and about the method of doing trade in Asian countries; and it is time that we had representative offices there. Far too many Australian business people flying into countries such as Thailand with a contract in their briefcases walk up to an Asian firm and expect to get a contract signed on the spot and catch an aeroplane back home. They go home wondering why they have not got their contract signed. Sometimes the arrogance of us as a people never ceases to amaze me. It is almost as if we expect the world to bow before us and buy the produce that we have to sell in a world which is increasingly competitive. We will be successful only if we go out and we meet the Asian markets equally with intelligence and with education and they will buy from us; there is no argument about that. Australia is seen as a friendly nation in Asia. Australia is seen as a nation which has a lot to offer in services, in education and in technology and Asian countries want joint ventures with Australia.

Recently I had dinner in Melbourne with Dr Arthit, who is the leader of the Community Party of Thailand. He was in Australia desperately looking for joint ventures in education and for assistance in hospital management and in building new hospitals. Businesses in Thailand want Australians to be involved yet we, as a nation, are still not prepared to forget our past, to look to our future and create these new markets. Frankly, it is a worry to me. We do not have time. The EEC increasingly is looking inward. Whatever we manage to achieve in the Uruguay Round in terms of agricultural trade, the reality is that our market to the EEC is very small. We are bit players in markets as large as the EEC and we are bit players in the America market. Those markets look to each other rather than to us. Frankly, the time is running out for this country unless we get off our tails and we actually get out there and become aggressive in those new Asian markets. I implore this Parliament and all members in this House to remember that in future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I do not intend to dwell at too much length on the comments of the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), I must support his comments on the need for future development of Asian-Australian links in terms of our international trade. I was also privileged to be a member of the informal delegation to Thailand that he mentioned and I can confirm some of his comments. In particular I commend his comments regarding the operations of Australian businesses in South East Asia because in many respects Australian business can be its own worst enemy. Dozens of instances could be quoted of Australian businesses going into some Asian markets and literally doing just that. Businesses have gone in with a contract in their briefcase and 24 hours later have left the place wondering why they have not got the business. Until such time as major Australian players are prepared to establish offices in Asian capitals, and until they are prepared to put specialist staff there who learn the customs and business practices of those nations, we can only get the crumbs. If government can do no more than assist to an even greater extent than perhaps it has in the past in being able to provide leadership and direction for Australian businesses to get into some of these ever-expanding markets, the whole situation of government is worth while.

SPEECH.PARA: There are tremendous opportunities for Australian businesses in South East Asia. There are tremendous opportunities for joint ventures. I add my weight to the plea for Australia to provide an even greater role in terms of education for South East Asian nations. One of the great tragedies in this country is the fact that we do not regard education as an export industry. Although some honourable members might have some doubts about the operation of the Bond University, I sincerely hope that the Bond University, on the Gold Coast, has a capacity to show to the Australian population that we can get into international markets and not only make money out of our tremendous resources but, by the influence of Australian educational institutions, help develop those links, ties and friendships especially with the Asian-Pacific region. While I agree that we must get into the Asian area, we must never forget that Australia has a major responsibility in terms of the South Pacific, particularly the South-West Pacific. We have obligations to ensure that we do all we possibly can for those nations that strategically are so important to this country.

The honourable member for McEwen might suggest that I am going to start whingeing again, but I thought that tonight I would spend a couple of moments bringing to the attention of the House Australia's new poor. While in the last few days of this debate, there have been many references to high interest rates and the difficulties that young people face in getting a home, I suggest that there is a forgotten generation of Australians. They are people aged between about 25 and 40 with an income of between about $23,000 and $45,000 a year. Those people have been absolutely forgotten by the Government and, I would suggest, to a great extent have been forgotten in this debate over the last few days. It is those people who are having incredible difficulty at the moment in making ends meet and, in many cases, providing shelter for their family.

In my electorate of Fadden, which falls on the outskirts of Brisbane, there are some shocking examples of what the interest rate regime is doing to people-married people on a single income and with a couple of children at home. I am sad to say that in some parts of my electorate people are literally closing the doors of their houses, walking away from them and saying, `That's it. No longer can I afford to maintain this roof over the heads of my wife and children'. There are numerous examples of that happening throughout Australia. We must never forget that it is the people who have made the commitment of marriage, the people who have had their children and who are trying to bring them up as best they can that have, to a very great degree, been forgotten by the Government and a great number of honourable members as we debate some of the grave economic problems facing the nation.

If we are to get this housing thing right, there must be even greater cooperation between all levels of government. It is not only a case of bringing up the stock; it is a case of looking at the whole system of home purchase in Australia and at the difficulties facing our young people in particular. One looks at what is being charged for conveyancing these days by some members of the legal profession. We all know that most conveyancing is done in legal offices by 16- and 17-year-old clerks. One looks at the tremendous up-front costs that people are required to pay in terms of State stamp duties and transfer duties in order to get their own homes. Surely there must be a sense of cooperation to ensure that Australians can at least get a decent roof over their heads.

The housing debate goes on and the emphasis, rightly so, is on the current incredible interest rates. I was shocked to learn today that in my State of Queensland at present 28 per cent of the earnings of a person on the average income is required to meet his home loan repayments. That is a great indictment on the state of the nation. We should be doing everything that we possibly can to try to provide some relief, whether from the Federal Government, State governments or local governments, to make it possible for people to own their own home. It has always been one of the basic tenets of Australian society that it is the right of all people to own their own home. While we languished, I suppose, in the joy of knowing that about 80 per cent of the Australian population had the capacity to own their own home, that percentage is falling fast and will continue to fall fast unless there are some drastic examinations of infrastructural charges and government charges generally. Most importantly, we must provide some economic relief, especially for middle income earners-those people on single incomes with a couple of children and making between $23,000 and $45,000. They are the people who are finding it very difficult to make ends meet.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been forgotten.

—They are the forgotten Australians and that makes me very sad. I was interested to hear the excellent speech made by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) tonight regarding the plight of small business in Australia. My electorate probably contains more small businesses, or has a higher concentration of small businesses, than most other Australian electorates. Principally they fall in the Logan City area, which borders the south of Brisbane. It is now Queensland's second largest city, with a population of 150,000. It is a very new city; it has been in existence for only 10 years. However, it has on its books something like 4,800 small businesses. The worry is that there is now a 15 per cent turnover a year in those businesses. Over the last few years all sorts of government programs have been put up because one of the sad things about Logan City is that it has one of the highest rates of unemployment for young people anywhere in Australia. That unemployment rate has hit a level as high as 25 per cent. A number of schemes have been introduced by government and other agencies to try to overcome that unemployment rate. There was a great deal of interest, and certainly quite an amount of support, last year when it was announced that there would be a joint venture between the Commonwealth Government and the Logan City Chamber of Commerce to introduce an information and technology centre in Logan City. Some politics were played in terms of the physical location of what is now known as the Information Technology Education Centre (ITEC), but there was a spirit of goodwill between the three Federal members who represent Logan City, and we were pleased to see the development get off the ground, despite some of the initial problems in terms of the location and the type of building that was to be provided.

SPEECH.PARA: However, that scheme is now in jeopardy. It has been operating for just on six months and it looks like going under. The principal reason for that is Federal Government funding, but there are other reasons too. Small businesses have perhaps not got behind the Logan Chamber of Commerce or the local city council as best they could to make the thing work. At the outset, ITEC in Logan City was told that it would be provided with $200,000 in establishment moneys from the Federal Government to make the project work. At the moment it has a $110,000 shortfall. Nobody is quite sure what has happened to that other $110,000 that was coming from the Federal Government to make the project work. I appeal to the Government tonight to ensure that the commitment that it made up-front to the city council, the Board of ITEC and the Logan Chamber of Commerce, the co-sponsor of this operation, for that extra $110,000 is met immediately. The last thing that I think anybody in that area wants to see is the project going under, but there is a very real chance of that happening if the money is not forthcoming, despite the fact that the Logan Chamber of Commerce says that it will do all it possibly can to keep the thing afloat so it can bring new high technology industries into that very important part of south-east Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members may recall recently receiving correspondence asking for help in raising funds for the Don Mackay Griffith Gatehouse. The money was to be raised by having a run from Sydney to Griffith. The amount to be raised was $100,000. The Don Mackay Griffith Gatehouse is used for the rehabilitation of people who have been on drugs or alcohol, mainly young people. It is a very worthwhile cause that the people of Griffith have taken up in answer to the bad publicity that Griffith has received over the years, which has been earned for it by a very small minority of people. The people of Griffith are determined that they will do something about the drug problem and the rehabilitation of young people.

SPEECH.PARA: The run was launched by Barbara Mackay from Sydney on 29 March. The runners included people such as Wal McCrorie. People may remember that name. He was the first winner of the run from Sydney to Melbourne and he has run in a number of races since then. I thank Ian Whitfield, Steve Nordich, Ian Hutchinson and Tina Campbell for taking part in that run. I also thank a gentleman by the name of Nobbie Young, who was one of the chief organisers, but he had to pull out because of a chest infection. I also thank the supporters who were in the support vehicles for their contribution. Many of those people are members of the Sydney Striders Club.

I thank those honourable members who answered the letters that were forwarded to them asking for support, although the replies were not many. The money they put forward will play a significant part in rehabilitating young people who have a drug problem. I congratulate Barbara Mackay-most people know Barbara, Don Mackay's widow-who has done a great deal of work. She is a very brave woman and has taken on this crusade in order to care for people who are affected by drugs. She is involved in many other organisations in Griffith and throughout Australia.

Beres Sexton is a very courageous young man and a great friend of mine. He decided to organise the run and did a great job there. The run ended on 2 April, the final day of the Griffith Food and Wine Festival. John Dickie, the organiser of that festival, and Jan Evans were there on that day. I congratulate and thank them for the great part they played in trying to raise funds for the Griffith Gatehouse Foundation.

I offer my congratulations and thanks to the people of the great town of Griffith, and to the people who supported the run and the final day of the festival, on supporting the Don Mackay Griffith Gatehouse. I ask members of the House who may not have replied to the letter and now know what it is all about and would like to contribute, or anyone else, to please help this Foundation because it does great work. I know that Barbara Mackay would be very grateful, as would all the people who really do care for those who have got themselves into all sorts of strife through drugs and alcohol.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bernie Newson of Cooma, a Vietnam veteran, is totally and permanently disabled due to war caused injuries while on war service in Vietnam. In letters to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) Mr Newson has concentrated on the report of the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. He has concentrated on discrepancies he has found in the report and he has asked me to help him and thousands of other veterans in getting that message across.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Newson wants the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to consider American declassified documents that completely contradict the findings of the Royal Commission. Bernie Newson has quoted the declassification numbers so that the Minister can identify them. He has also pointed out that Senator Paul McLean has the documents in his possession. I have been advised that the Minister has not been forwarded the documents. Recently I telephoned Senator McLean and he has agreed to provide the declassified documents so that the points can be examined.

What worries Mr Newson and the International Independent Agent Orange Network, for which he is research director, is that the Evatt Royal Commission findings were too closed. The Royal Commission left many veterans feeling that they were not fairly dealt with in the report and the scientific and legal evidence was lacking for some of the report's conclusions.

I appreciate that a public affairs conference is being conducted at the Australian National University-a conference entitled `Evatt Revisited-Interpretation of Scientific Evidence'. This will address some of the problems raised by Bernie Newson and his fellow veterans. I also appreciate that Mr Bob Hogg in his examination of the Evatt findings said that it was too early to speak out about the chemical effects on humans with such absolute certainty.

I know that the Minister has said that the Government will continue to monitor health trends within the Vietnam veterans' community through the Department of Veterans' Affairs database. He has not ruled out the possibility that agent orange may be shown to be linked to the existing problems of veterans. Having left the door open, the Minister has shown that new material will be properly considered. There is new material on super orange and it is coming forward in the United States of America. This material needs to be on the Minister's desk.

Our colleague in the Senate, Senator Paul McLean, has the declassified documents I have mentioned. I would like the Minister to peruse them. Senator McLean has kindly offered to make them available. Along with the conference on the Royal Commission and the Minister's own determination to keep the door open for new information, the documents and other new material may prevent far more costly and legally complex actions by an important group in our community which seeks justice. Literally thousands of Vietnam veterans are relying on a fair and equitable solution to their everyday problems. They deserve honour and dignity even if it is 25 years after the event.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last week I had the opportunity to visit two institutions in my electorate. I wish to share those experiences with the House. The first was the diamond jubilee of the Hillcrest Hospital, which is an adjunct of the Royal Adelaide Hospital. It has done a lot in the servicing of psychiatric patients and it is an excellent caring centre. At Hillcrest a strong emphasis is placed on research and this has been fostered in a number of ways. The board of management has offered a number of research fellowships for students in disciplines related to psychiatry and these have been highly successful with almost 10 times as many applicants from all States of Australia as there were fellowships available. It is planned that these be continued to foster research in areas particularly appropriate to the service needs of this hospital.

SPEECH.PARA: The feature was a delightful chapel service on a mild autumn day in Hillcrest in the northern suburbs of Adelaide and its simplicity was classic in its example. The history and the vision of the Hillcrest Hospital were introduced by Mr Rob Iversen. The first reading was from John, Chapter I, by Mr David Seaton, who is now the chairman of that board. An excellent group of men and women make up and complement the Hillcrest Hospital board. The second reading was by Dr Norman James. His theme was `Out of the darkness and into light'. The address was by Pastor Lloyd John. There was a delightful choral item by a quartet of singers from the Uniting Church Parish of Islington. Their choral work was entitled All in the April Evening and Let There be Peace.

The introduction to the memorial roll was by Mrs Yvette Amer and probably the most emotionally charged address was by Mrs Bette Figg, who unveiled the memorial roll. Just to cap off the day, the unveiling of the plaque took place under some delightful trees in the garden. The memorial roll contains names including James Bell, Charles Bywater, Patrick Gaffney, Edith Gaitskill, Thomas Leahy, Shirley Lofts, Leslie McLeay, Kathleen McMillan, Lee Makk, Peter Mason, Ronald Miller, Cyril Pratt, Stirling Robertson, James Sinclair, Tim Vallance, Joyce Williams, Charles Williamson, Walter Wiltshire, Maxine Woods and Jessie Cavanagh, a delightful lady who nursed and worked hard and long.

On Saturday morning in Rundle Mall in Adelaide I had the opportunity to declare open Jaycees Week in conjunction with another excellent program that it is involved with, that is, the organ donation and transplantation program that the Australian Kidney Foundation is working on around Australia. Jaycees is a non-political, non-sectarian organisation of men and women aged 18 to 40 years. It initiated the Buy Australia campaign and the clean up campaign which was known as KESAB. It was there promoting its cause and giving away kits which demonstrated the life-giving opportunities that Medic Alert provided. Mr Warwick Prime, a former media commentator in South Australia and Western Australia, is now wearing a second hat, being involved with the Australian Kidney Foundation at Wavell. There I saw living testimony to what organ donation can do. Sue, Brian and Angela were there. Sue had a liver transplant. She was a delightful young lady who, without a liver transplant, would have led a life full of misery which would have led to her death. Angela, another delightful young lady, had renal failure and required a kidney transplant, which enables her still to ride horses. The most gratifying thing was that she gave birth to a child which was healthy. Finally, there was Brian, who had had a heart transplant. He made the very pragmatic statement that as long as he lives his donor is alive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this adjournment debate to express my disappointment with the Israeli Government for refusing to negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organisation and to end the killing and violence on the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Mr Shamir's proposals to give some municipal autonomy to selected Arabs to be able to decide how to dispose of the garbage and waste there does not fool anybody. Calls for peace are coming from all around the world.
—Ha, ha!

—They are not coming from the honourable member for Adelaide. Evidently he enjoys the killings. There are very strong calls for peace, including ones from within Israel itself. A prominent sign of lack of universal Israeli support for the war is the popular Shalom Achshaw movement, which if my Hebrew is still correct means `peace now', and the growing number of soldiers who refuse to serve in the occupied territories.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, Yesh Gvul, which means `have borders' and which is the organisation of these military refuseniks, announced its fiftieth case since the start of the Intifada. Fifty young Israeli servicemen have so far been gaoled for their refusal to repress the Palestinian people. Many more have similarly refused but have been transferred to other duties instead of being given harsher punishments. I would like to read from a letter sent by one reservist announcing his resignation from the Israeli defence forces:

. . . I am not willing to be part of any army of occupation which uses the same kind of methods as were used, in the past, against the Jewish people-such as the murder of women and children and the beating to death of old men. For reasons of conscience, I declare my complete resignation from this army which-rather than defend the country-serves as an instrument of brutal rule over and oppression of another people . . .

After repeated refusals to serve, this man, Mr Ephraim Shirman, was imprisoned and started a hunger strike. There have been demonstrations in support of his stand, demanding the right to conscientious objection. It seems incongruous that a country which presents itself as one that respects the principles of human rights should refuse to recognise a person's right to be a conscientious objector.

In another interesting example, Mr Hillel Bardin, a reserve officer in the West Bank town of Ramallah who was sickened by the needless violence of his job, negotiated with local Palestinian youths to stop breaking up demonstrations and meetings as long as they remained peaceful.

This prevented violence for some weeks until some Jewish settlers found out. The officer was imprisoned and the conflict was resumed. It is surprising only that more soldiers do not refuse to participate in the crushing of the Intifada. A recent court martial of four soldiers from a brigade known as the Purple Berets revealed that soldiers had been given explicit orders from commanding officers to beat up Palestinians when arresting them. In this instance, these soldiers beat an old man to death.

It is time that this violence against the oppressed Palestinian people ended. It is up to all peace-loving people to continue to put pressure on the Israeli Government to take the necessary steps towards peace in the region. Specifically, they should urge the Israeli Government to take advantage of the willingness of the Palestine Liberation Organisation to negotiate the settlement of the dispute. Having recently visited the Middle East on a fact finding mission I can assure members that there is a strong yearning for peace on the part of the Palestinians. The responsibility for achieving this peace now rests on the shoulders of Israel's political leaders, and I call on our Government to use all its influence to persuade the Israelis to negotiate under the auspices of the United Nations to end the unlawful occupation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last month while attending the Inter-Parliamentary Union conference at Budapest in Hungary I took the opportunity with Senator Shirley Walters from Tasmania to visit the Commonwealth War Graves cemetery at Solymar some 14 kilometres to the south of Budapest. I understand the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) also visited these war graves at a later time during the conference. I raise this matter here tonight because these particular war graves would not be very well known to many Australians. I had not heard of them before my visit to Hungary. It was a moving experience to drive out into the open countryside where the war graves are located and to inspect them at first hand. I am delighted to report that they are in excellent condition, with the lawns recently having been returfed, no doubt at some considerable expense, and with everything else looking spick and span.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that many members in this chamber will have inspected war graves in various countries, including some of the famous ones in countries like France. However, to visit this little-known cemetery in that distant part of the world and to see first hand the headstones and graves and surroundings so beautifully kept made me feel very proud.

There are 208 airmen buried in the cemetery. One hundred and twenty-three come from the Royal Air Force, 37 from the Polish Air Force-because it was fighting with us at the time-21 from the South African Air Force; 13 from the Royal Australian Air Force; six from the Royal Canadian Air Force; and six from the Royal New Zealand Air Force. As well, there were two unidentified airmen and one person from the 1914-18 war, who was a seaman of the Royal Navy. These airmen buried in the cemetery lost their lives during raids over Hungary between April and November 1944. The raids were made from Italian bases on industrial targets in Gyor and Budapest and also on German troop concentrations in other parts of Hungary. The raids were quite successful. The industrial target raids alone knocked out five of the seven big oil refineries in Hungary.

After the war, attempts were made to trace the graves of the airmen who had died there in Hungary. Advertisements were placed in the national press and in the local press in regions where the aircraft were known to have been shot down. Letters were also written to local authorities. As a result of this, some 58 bodies were recovered. The Hungarian Government purchased the land for the cemetery in October 1946 from a local landowner and gave it to the United Kingdom in July 1947 for a military cemetery. There is a plaque there in the wall of the cemetery with an inscription which reads:
The land on which this Cemetery stands is the gift of the People of Hungary for the perpetual resting place of the airmen who are honoured there.

Later in 1947 a proper burial took place. Between 1950 and 1954 the original wooden crosses were replaced with proper cement headstones as found in the other Commonwealth war graves around the world. It was a very sobering experience to move round, read the words on the headstone of each grave and see that so-and-so died at age 20, someone else at 21 and someone else at 23. It was almost rare to find someone who died later than the age of 26. These headstones are a perpetual reminder of such a tragic waste of young lives, as the shadow Minister looking after veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), acknowledges.

Two ceremonies are held each year at these war graves, one on the Hungarian Liberation Day in April and the other, which is a remembrance day service, in November. I was saddened to learn that, though the ambassadors of all the Commonwealth countries attend these ceremonies as well as representatives of the Hungarian Government and the Polish Ambassador, where appropriate, no invitation is extended to the South African Government to send a representative. There are more South African airmen resting in the cemetery than Australians, New Zealanders or Canadians. They fought with the allies and gave their lives to help rid the world of Nazism. They knew nothing of the system of government we so delight in criticising in their country today. It was not until 1948 that its system of government formally began. I will never understand how we can be a partner to such small minded pettiness in denying these fallen heroes a representative from their country to honour them each year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to place on record my total agreement with the previous two speakers. The honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) has played a very lonely and quite a brave part in his support for the people of Palestine, and the views of the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) should also be well and truly heeded.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk tonight about hypocrisy, which is alive and well in this country and flourishes nowhere as successfully as in the media. The Government of Western Australia has been subjected to constant attacks from the press for what was called Western Australia Inc. It has been suggested that the Government was involved with big business in some way that was detrimental to the people. This is totally absurd. The press itself has never been put under any scrutiny. If one looks at the situation in Western Australia, one sees that these attacks from the media came principally from three sources. The Fairfax Press, which at one time was without peer in Australia and was probably an example to the world in terms of a free press, is certainly an organisation with a noble history. However, I am sad to say that that has apparently changed. The Fairfax Press made constant attacks on the Western Australian Government and the Bond Corporation. When one looks at the situation one realises that Bond was in fact financing litigation against them. They were intent on attacking Bond, feeling that any attack on Bond strengthened their position. The record will show that they eventually settled out of court for some $49m. There was clearly a vested interest there, and this was never recognised by the rest of the media or by many members of the Opposition.

The second arm of the attack was the Murdoch Press. I can find very little to say about the Murdoch Press that is favourable. The Murdoch Press clearly has a vested interest. It has been the aim of Murdoch to get control of what is probably the most profitable newspaper in Australia. I do not think there is any secret that it has harboured the desire for a long time to get hold of the media interests owned by the Bond Corporation. So it too had a vested interest in these continued attacks.

The third arm was the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). I do not know what one can say about the ABC. This organisation, which I used to be particularly proud of, is particularly contemptible. What can be said for the ABC is that, after the very cowardly and ill-informed attack on the Four Corners program, at least the 7.30 Report program tried to make some redress. What motivates the ABC? It cannot be profit; it cannot be hope of gain. It is something even more cowardly: it is its sort of camp dog attitude as it yaps after the besieged seeking to be in it as well-the me-tooism attitude. It is my view that there are elements of the ABC that are dominated by what I would call kindergarten marxism. The Four Corners program is a classic example.

I also want to draw the attention of the House to what else has happened. The Western Australian Government did not lose money in its trading. All its trading arms in fact made substantial profits. They were wound up by a Premier who, I guess, lost his nerve. They have been wound up at a time when no venture capital is available in Western Australia. I hope that some alternative will be put into place. One looks at what happened in Victoria, where large amounts of money were lost, where the national media had hardly a word to say, or at the outrage that has occurred in New South Wales where the Premier, Mr Greiner, has given a $92m handout to the Fairfax organisation. He has rebated $92m of stamp duty owing by that organisation. Anyone who does not believe that one can buy political clout and political partisanship with $92m is living in fairyland. It is a disgraceful and dangerous precedent and one which the whole nation should be well aware of. I certainly hope-and I will be pursuing the matter-that any assistance is docked from the amount of money that the New South Wales Government could and should have recouped from the Fairfax organisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday evening I organised a meeting in the township of Norton Summit in my electorate in order for local people to protest to the Civil Aviation Authority about the building of a radar tower at Marble Hill. I regard the decision of the Civil Aviation Authority to go ahead with this project as bone-headed, arrogant and insensitive. I am only sorry that I was unable to get to that meeting. I was delayed by the air traffic controllers in Sydney who were taking industrial action. I actually was not able to get to Adelaide until the next day. But I am grateful to the Mayor of East Torrens, Isobel Bishop, for chairing that meeting in my place.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal of the Civil Aviation Authority to build a radar tower in the Adelaide Hills is anathema to the thousands of South Australians who want to preserve the beauty of the Adelaide Hills. The people that made the decision to build this monstrosity live in far-off Canberra. My talks with them reveal they know next to nothing about the Adelaide Hills or its people and that they care even less about the environmental implications of their decision. They already have one of their horrible towers at Summertown. A commonsense solution would have been to remove that tower and replace it with one more appropriate to the needs of the Civil Aviation Authority.

The Civil Aviation Authority prepared a report on the proposal for me which was totally inadequate. The figures were rubbery and the conclusions vague. We now learn the Civil Aviation Authority has decided to make full use of its legal privileges arrogantly to dismiss my protests, to overrule State planning laws and to give the local council the flick.

Ever since I can remember I seem to have been waging war against government authorities smashing up the Adelaide Hills with their so-called vital facilities. It does not seem to matter one jot to them that we, the people of the Hills, have our own views about our local environment. Television towers, freeways, communication masts, cable cars, massive and ugly hotel complexes on Mount Lofty summit-up they all go without a care in the world for the views of the local people in the Adelaide Hills.

I will continue to pursue this arrogant attitude of the Civil Aviation Authority, its decision which was ill-founded, its decision which lacked any consultation whatsoever with local people prior to purchasing the property and going ahead with its decision to build the tower-a decision which holds all those who love the Adelaide Hills in complete contempt. I hope in future other government organisations eschew this sort of path that the Civil Aviation Authority has chosen. It is a new authority with new found independence. In my view, it has made a very poor start. I hope it will learn from this mistake. Perhaps my final plea, as we move to 11 o'clock, is for the Civil Aviation Authority to think yet again and to cancel its stupid decision to desecrate the environment of the Adelaide Hills.
